150175082.review:
I played this game on beta in early access, and omg is it adorable. I love love love the graphics. I was very sad to reach the end of available gameplay, and am currently going through little witch in the woods withdrawal. 

Ellie, our little witch apprentice, is quite the character - an impatient mischief-maker with a heart of gold. The dialogue between her and her talking hat is amusing, to say the least. 

Story-wise, Ellie is supposed to be going to a town to apprentice with a senior witch, but during the journey, the train has an unexpected stop, and because she hates being on the train to begin with, she decides to take a midnight trek through the woods to visit a tree she saw from the window. She ends up spending the night in an abandoned witch's cabin and misses the train leaving the next morning. But no big loss, because she didn't want to go to that town anyway! She finds a village and begins helping the people there, as a good witch apprentice does, although she has to pretend she has a senior witch overlooking her training (her hat fills in for the senior witch lol). The goal is to rebuild the town, which was decimated by some mysterious vine, and bring back the old villagers. 

Gameplay includes exploring the countryside, discovering plants and animals and harvesting supplies from them to use for potions, and doing various quests for the villagers. Ellie has a notebook she carries around in which she records the plant
and animal life. Achievements and more information about each entry are given if you meet certain requirements such as collecting a certain amount, collecting during a certain time of day, or if you find rare specimens. Rewards are given with increases in rank, and Ellie gets gifts or money for completing the book at certain intervals, like 25% complete and so on. 

Gameplay mechanics worked well for me on PC, although the keys used to play were a little strange - using the arrow keys to move, z as an action key, d to open your notebook, etc. I got used to them, but they aren't exactly intuitive. Perhaps I could change the config, but I didn't try so I can't comment on that. 

I had only a few issues while playing: 

Evidently, you are supposed to befriend the villagers, but I'm unsure if this is an aspect that isn't included in the game yet, or if it just isn't something I can tell is happening. You have options to have various conversations with the villagers, and it says you have become closer to the person when you do them, but this repeats on an endless loop as far as I could tell, and nothing special happened after several such conversations. There was no way to measure friendship level. 

There were a few bugs: some text that didn't fit in the dialogue box, one of the quests opened a blank visual window that hung around and blocked conversations until I finished that quest, and when I was given the witch's broom, I was unable to ride it right away, although once I slept that issue resolved. Not sure I see the point of the broom though, as it seems to go slower than Ellie can walk XD 

One other complaint I have is that the dialogue is a little... excessive. It's humorous at times, but I don't want to read through 20 text boxes every time I have a conversation with someone. There were points where I was barely reading them at all because I was bored and just wanted to get on with the quest and collect some bunny fur. 

At the end of the available content, I was given the ability to upgrade and decorate the witch's cabin, which I was excited about. Unfortunately, there were no more quests available, and it would've been tedious to play just to fill orders for the merchants (which refresh every wed and sun) to earn money to decorate.  

I would absolutely recommend this game based on what I've played so far. My complaints are ultimately minor and didn't affect my overall enjoyment. I'm definitely looking forward to future content (I want to decorate my cabin, dang it!).

150150919.review:
This is a very good cozy game that does everything right. you are a witch. you spend your time doing witch things and helping villagers in ways that **visibly improve the town!!!** This game does a lot of things very well that others don't.

We don't have bloated "life sim" mechanics. No, you can't farm, nor fish, nor play 20 different minigames, because that's not the point! why would a witch farm?! There is clearly inspiration from games like stardew valley, but just like stardew's improvement of the harvest moon franchise, this game knows what to take and what to leave behind. It makes the world feel incredibly complete and leaves the gameplay loop concise. 

The movement of your character is also very good. your walk isn't slow, and there's a sprint. Then you have brooms, that let you move quite a bit faster but take resources to maintain, as well as having floatier physics. It's not like the controls are show stopping, but they are better than most. 

Gathering resources is different for each type, as it's mostly magical creatures, and most also have a couple secrets to make gathering easier / more lucrative. There's an overflowing level of charm and care put into these little critters. 

The potions you make have actual impact! Many of them can be used to get a large amount of a specific resource, and/or for puzzles throughout the map. You honestly rarely sell potions, instead making and selling magic candies that are specifically created for non-witches. Again, this makes the gameplay feel great: your potion making progress has clear benefits to your future potion making, it's not all about money. 

Gathering items spends energy. Crafting potions notably does *not* spend energy. This little improvement makes the gameplay loop amazing, as even if you exhaust yourself picking items, you can spend the rest of the night crafting potions rather than twiddling your thumbs. 

The story is good, especially the main character. Thank the heavens, she's not a silent self insert protagonist! She has a personality, and is generally mischievous but well meaning. The other villagers and characters you meet are also well written and have cohesive character traits. Currently a friendship/affinity system is maybe in the process of being added, but it's not really important because, again, we have well written story and characters. 

Speaking of characters: town improvement! Sidequests and main quests improve the town in ways more significant than just unlocking new items in the shop. You build houses, add streetlights, etc. and change a decrepit town containing 3 people into a moderately larger one. I know it's more work on the developer's part, but the building improvement mechanics are amazing in this game. 

The grind isn't that heavy, for the most part. This is definitely a personal preference thing, but it's not particularly difficult to get a large number of any resources, as long as you are willing to commit a day to collecting them. Yes, later upgrades get more expensive, but in a "takes several in game days" not "takes an in-game season" type of way. 

Currently, the Beta build of the game has massive feature (and story progression) improvements from the stable base game (which is still amazing), but is expectedly buggy, so it's up to you if you want to play the beta from the get go or not.

149996866.review:
Even though the game is in early access, I had a blast and was able to get 10 hours of content out of it so far. Definitely recommend this to casual players who enjoy a nice story, fun characters and want to explore without feeling pressured.

The playstyle is reminiscent of Stardew Valley, but with a witchy flavour which I enjoyed. 
I adore the art and the flora&fauna and the fact that some gathering materials you can get by playing or petting animals. Very cute.
The encyclopedia is very useful and easy to get used to.
Gathering materials is easy because everything spawns at the same location. 
There was no real reason to upgrade much so far, but I can definitely see this being a thing with more ingame content and it's fun to optimize.

There's only three downsides to the currect content for me.
1) When I start a game, I am eager to start moving and figuring things out. Unfortunately this game starts with a dialogue that you can't get out of and the content is supposed to give you an idea of who Ellie is and what she's doing, but I found it to be quite long-winded. 
2) It takes a lot of time to get out of a conversation with someone. The many times I have to cancel menu after menu gets frustrating. 
3) You can do side quests to earn money and Luna coins. Nothing wrong with that, but please can I make something else besides curse lifting candy? The amount of times both Diana and Aurea asked for these took the joy right out of it. More variation is key.

149943796.review: This game is so cozy and cute! I really hope to see it reach completion and watch the plot develop while it goes.

149908151.review:
LOVE the potential this game has to be incredible. the story is intricate, unique, and engaging. I love going to new areas and having my little character draw each new one with her quill! the writing is fantastic, the art is stunning - detailed, rich, enchanting - and the market system is balanced and fair.

my gripes so far are not enough to prevent anyone from getting the game, but things to be aware of:
- everyone in the reviews say that the keyboard layout is weird. it's... WEIRD. and you can't change the layout. I was stuck on the home screen pressing random buttons until i figured out what worked. and pay attention - because pressing shift to tiptoe is told to you once. if you forget it... it's not listed as a feature in the settings section either. you get used to it over time, but I hope the devs consider changing the layout or offering the option for the player to customize the keybindings to fit their preferred play style.
- the game is in early access so it is to be expected that there are certain QoL features that are lacking. there definitely could be a better way to process ingredients and potions to save time. in addition, it would be nice if ingredients that are stored in the chest in the basement would be automatically factored into processing machines and the cauldron without having to pull them out manually every time. 
- the game saves after you wake up for the day and start to move out of the house. the character and screen freeze for a few seconds before letting you know it's saved. it is slightly game-breaking and clunky - I wonder if this save could be moved to the dream animation that plays for a few seconds while your character is sleeping?
- it would be nice to use a mouse to be able to select specific things of interest in the environment. for example, trying to weed out one of the ruined houses and accidentally clicking on the house over and over and over again and prompting the dialogue box to pop up over and over. just a little annoying!
- okay this is my *biggest* gripe. you cannot go to sleep before the clock hits 8pm. even if you are out of stamina. you cannot send the day over to the next manually. even if there is nothing left to do in the game story wise. I guess you could nap to regain stamina, but sometimes I'm just done with that day and want to move on to the next. it takes a bit of control from the player and seems so frustrating when it is 7:50pm in the game and I am just standing by the bed, idle, waiting for the time to turn over. 

all this being said, I fully believe the devs will take care of this game and polish it up to be something truly extraordinary. it is already one of my favorite gems of a game and has brought me so much joy! it's been so long since I was so invested in a game like this and I cannot wait to follow it's progress and see where the devs take this GEM! if you like stardew, kiki's delivery service, teenage exocolonist, strange horiculture, and any potion-making game of your liking - you will love this.

145697937.review:
~Wholesome, charming, compelling. Satisfying gameplay~
ART~ This is the best early access game I have ever played. First of all, the art in this game is hands down the most beautiful pixel art I have ever seen. Even if someone usually doesn't like pixel art, I feel like it would be hard to be anything but charmed by this. 
CHARACTERS ~ Beyond the art, the substance of this game is truly present. The main character, Ellie, is so spirited. Her personality comes alive immediately and is so endearing. The other characters also feel very distinct and lovable. 
STORY~ RPG as a young witch who is on the train on the way to her apprenticeship, but there is an interruption. While the train has been stopped, she gets off to explore around the area and finds an old witches house and the remains of a village named Wisteria. The land has been overgrown with magical vines and most of the residents have moved away from the village. Ellie , spirited and kind-hearted as she is, promises to stay and do what she can to help this town (since she ended up missing her train anyways). 
GAME PLAY~ This game has such fun game mechanics. You are involved in every part of magical study and practice- from identification of different plant/animal species, all of which have their own environments, mannerisms, and methods of gathering materials for use. While there is no combat in this game (which was not a problem for me, I actually preferred it), you still get good tension by having to use stealth to sneak up on certain creatures and not scare them off, with a reward of sweet, sweet endorphins when you manage it. You can prepare ingredients in different methods such as roasting and extracting, and ultimately brew them in potions that you can use on yourself or to interact with the environment (such as using potions to get rid of the vines, or to grow plants as platforms that you can walk on to access other areas). 
You can also sell potions and take on optional daily orders for in-game currency. 
VIBE~ The vibe is spot on with this one, and really makes the game. I have never played a game that feels so magical as this. The music is gorgeous and pairs well with the mysterious vibe and natural beauty of this game. The plants and creatures are different during the day as they are at night. It is so satisfying to see this environment transform and come alive.  You really feel like you are a witch, studying these plants and animals, filled with so much wonder and awe. 

I really, really recommend this game. It is well worth the price. And if you are worried about it being early access, don't be! I have gotten over 13 hours in so far and the developers are just going to keep adding more environments, characters and story. But there is plenty here already to feel fleshed out and immersive. Little Witch in the Woods has fully captured my heart, and it is truly a one of a kind experience. I love cozy RPG games, which usually mean games that are farming sims to some extent. It is very refreshing to see this cozy game come out that totally breaks the mold and is an entirely different experience, without combat or farming, but is not lacking at all for that. <3

145656156.review:
I wanted to like this game but the sheer amount of dialogues to get through can be quite irritating due to its repetitiveness as they come up often throughout your quest or while exploring (constant reminders) which affects gameplay.
These dialogues cannot be skipped or fast forward either, I'd suggest the dev to cut down on the aimless chatter between the 2 characters. Although it gives certain depth into the personality & characteristics, most dialogues seem highly unnecessary and instead of being a cozy game that I can relax into, the seemingly endless dialogues just infuriated me.

Attempted playing with a controller and it's still clunky as I found that I had to resort to using my mouse/keyboard to open the Encyclopedia. In-game signs would sometimes still register the keyboard keys or mouse icon when interacting with objects.

Overall a cute game, has potential with plenty of great ideas, interesting characters and I can see why it's popular among cozy gamers.
This will be a great game if there can be some trimmings done/more further development in the final version.

144510403.review: Unfortunately I did not enjoy this game. There is a lot, and I mean - a LOT of dialogue . More than is shown in the trailer/gameplay. You'll interact other NPC's, but there is a constant annoying dialogue between the "little witch" (main character) and her hat. It goes on, and on - and its very juvenile sounding.. not important. I honestly feel like it was all very unnecessary and took away from the gameplay. It seems that nearly any time you need to pick up something, go to a new area, the hat is talking to you and the "little witch" is talking back . You get to a abandoned witch's house and start cleaning up the place and everytime you add an item to your inventory, its a conversation with the hat. Each time you clear some cobwebs, the witch is complaining about cleaning. Each time you remove weeds outside, she is complaining to the hat. The music , the concept , animation and everything is great - the dialogue just does not stop and it felt like I was in a cartoon for 7 year olds. There should be a setting to just shut it all off and have minimal , necessary conversation (sort of like stardew valley) - but there isn't.

I keep revisiting this over the year since I bought it in hopes it's improved, but it's a still a little too grindy and sparsely updated to recommend. For example the bulk of the opening quests you do all involve harvesting the same 3-4 things over and over before moving onto new things; but then there's side quests that involve re-harvesting the same 3-4 things you'd just finished doing. Not only do you need 2 of each component, you'll also need 100 branches, 100 coins, etc. etc, just to upgrade your inventory slots which barely last you from one section to the next. 

I'll revisit it again later, but for now I'd just keep an eye on this one.

142342259.review:
It is a really cute game but even though it has been released over a year ago it still has quiet a short quest line. I was collecting extra ingredients every day just in case i would need them and bam quests ended so im left with a chest full of extracts and branches. I know it is in early access but still doesn't have optimised mechanics, and receives updates pretty sparsely. I still enjoyed this relaxing game and don't mind my purchase since it's supporting the devs. Still would suggest people to wait for a sale instead of paying full price. Keep in mind my review is about live version and i did not try the beta version and if any of the issues i mention are already fixed in beta my apologies.

Some issues that were just annoying imo:
1- When you walk you can go any diagonal direction. But when you're sprinting you cannot run diagonal right+down or left+up which makes going around pretty slow and frustrating. Also sometimes when shaking a tree the progress bar gets interrupted for some reason, so you have to restart it.
2- Food is soo soo common which is nice I guess but as a punishment the max energy you can recover from food ticks down as time passes which makes big energy foods very obsolete. By the time i use up 200 energy, my max limit falls as well and half of a pie or bread energy goes to trash. make food more expensive and rare if that means you will remove or slow down the max energy cap decrease.
3- STORAGE!! Nothing stacks more than 10 (20 for building materials) and you end up having to hoard ingredients for buildings, quests, potions, upgrades etc but nothing nothing fits! Storage shouldnt be source of such pain in a relaxing pixel game imo, i was even turning everything into extracts and candies for better stacking but still had storage issues. When you expand your bag you do it only 4 slot at a time with ridiculously expensive gold price. When you expand your chest you again upgrade it only a couple slots at a time and need gold, branches and rocks too. Branches are common enough you can find 20+ a day but rocks are way less common.
4- Which brings me to my next point: prices of items are very out of balance. When you want to sell simple potions/candies that are not demanded by a daily quest they sell for such a low price (around 20 gold iirc might be wrong) it is just never worth it. But if you want to buy a rock it is 12 golds! but a food from arden that recovers whole 200 energy is only 25 gold. 
5- Don't know if it was a bug or it was just not developed yet but spoilers incoming. [spoiler] I made dream recall potion and drunk it around 3pm-ish after fixing fountain and finishing all quests until talking to people didnt give me anything new. Thought the cat said when you progress you can drink the potion and visit me or something along those lines and I was trying it for the first time. Never visited the cat for a second time and thought the end of the early access quest line would be progressed enough. But that night just nothing happened i only got the cute sketch dreams didn't meet cat and wasted my potion :( [/spoiler]

Lastly would love it if we got story and non story achievements. They make me feel like I actually progressed through a game and make me happy :) Will be waiting for the next big update to pick up the game again!

This is a really easy-going game. It's early access, so you're basically playing an introduction (I hope). 
If you, like me, loved Bear and Breakfast, this'll scratch your itch. It's nice.  

Some constructive criticism: 

-I counted three or four spelling errors along the way. It took me out of the immersion. :( 
-You can play all of it without upgrading all of the potion-making equipment at Ellie's house. :/ I just upgraded the extractor to level 1 and that was enough. It would be nice if, in the future, there were new quests that required the players to upgrade the potion-making equipment (maybe because there could be a lot of ingredients to extract/roast?). 
-I would love more Villager quests that make the player bond with them. That's something Bear and Breakfast did very elegantly. 

All in all, 7/10 early access.

139444824.review: I love this game from the bottom of my heart. It's early release right now, but that hasn't affected my gameplay at all so far. The art style is beautiful and the story is interesting and engaging, with cute NPCs who provide quests and trading opportunities. The potion crafting portion of the game allows for an in-game economy that encourages you to search for better ingredients and more complicated recipes, expanding your horizons and furthering your understanding of the world around you. This game is similar to Animal Crossing; there are tools you can use to catalog plants, animals and recipes, and you use the tools to collect the materials for those recipes. Different materials require different collection techniques. In addition, there are fun puzzles that you solve to progress through the storyline in order to help salvage and restore the village. I highly recommend this game to people who enjoy exploration and a relaxing gameplay experience.

139111057.review:
Little Witch in the Woods is a game I really want to enjoy. When I first heard about it, I was very excited for the concept, However, having played for a few hours... I just can't get myself to go back in the state that it's in.

For some positives, the game is beautiful. There is an incredible amount of effort in the sprite work and artwork for all the characters, and the various environments, and even some of the menus. The witch shop girl especially is just a beautiful piece of pixel art. The soundtrack is also fine, nothing great but not notably bad.

Unfortunately, the gameplay and writing just don't live up to the standards the art puts forward. It's very obvious that this is a team that does not natively speak English and have run the text through some automated translation program. You can get the gist of most things, but dialog comes off as clunky and unnatural in English. But even when you get the point of the dialog, it all feels... empty, is the best way I can describe it. Another review I read mentioned how bored the character kept saying they were at the start, and I felt that. I have zero connection with the plot due to how it is conveyed, and how you kind of just get plopped in.
The gameplay doesn't feel much better either. From what I can gather, the primary gameplay loop is to collect resources, brew potions, and sell them to merchants. You then use the currency to buy more potion recipes (To open new areas) or upgrade your potion brewing equipment/backpack ( to hold more potions). I guess I might not fully understand what being a witch is, but being in an endless loop of brewing potions is not really what I expected. Especially because it seems every part of those potions needs to be gathered out in the wild, you can't even grow your own materials. That on top of two loading screens being between you and the cauldron  makes it feel tedious, and just not fun.

I have tried numerous times to get myself to open this game back up, but I just can't bring myself to do it. I will probably try the game again when it releases fully, but for now I'll just wait. Maybe this just isn't the kind of game for me, as someone who might have been expecting something more Stardew-adjacent. But other than admiring the gorgeous artwork, I can't justify the time investment of playing the game.

138710048.review:
UPDATE: I didn't realize that if you download the game after the beta is released, you still need to go into the preferences for the game to update it. Once I did that, I had to restart the game from a selected chapter and redo some of the progress I'd made which was a little annoying but the gameplay is SIGNIFICANTLY better and hasn't crashed once. I'm so happy this is the case because I'd love to recommend this game. Its very cute and a great game to try out if you're into Stardew Valley or Wylde Flowers. 

----

First the cons: I've attempted less than four hours on this game, but with freezing on MacOS it is almost impossible to get through a day within the game without having to restart and redo what I'd done since the last save. This would be less frustrating if the game hadn't been out for a year with this being a known bug. Beyond freezing there have been one or two other bugs that require a restart to the software that seem to have been known for quite a while as well based on a quick google search.

The English translation also isn't very great and can make the story/task difficult to understand at times, but I could definitely look past that if the game wasn't nearly impossible to play. 

Pros: The art is great, the characters and story are adorable, and this is definitely a cozy game. If it were playable I'd recommend it to all my friends.

Overall, I do regret paying $15.99 for a game that does not work. I understand that Early Access comes with its expected bumps in the road, but there shouldn't be this many issues a year after release that render the game unplayable.

138514063.review:
This review is made in reference to the Little Witch in the Woods Discord server.

It's been a year and two days now since the release of LWitW Early Access, and I wanted to provide a bit of an organized recap of what we've been so far.
A lot of people, including myself, have purchased this game under the guise of there being a transparent workflow and incremental updates, as is normal with early access games.
In the events leading up to this game's public release, we've had numerous announcements in the ⁠dev-log channel, including the enemy Dubby, the painter Vinch, and a cave area to explore, all things still not in the public build of the game.

Since May 16th 2022 though, we have received three dev logs (7, 8, and 9) and only one meaningful patch update with multiple small bug fixes and languages added all close to the initial release of the game.

it pains me to say this, but in my opinion the dev logs listed have all been incredibly short , showcasing predominantly small mechanical and UI tweaks with a couple teasers of short gifs and still-images of gameplay to come.
Furthermore, the first two dev logs, 7 and 8, since release each have taken approximately two months to be posted (July 14th and September 6th), with the first and only content update of the game being on November 23rd (over six months since the release of the game in EA),
Our final dev log 9, whilst slightly bigger than the last two, has taken nearly 5 months since 8 was posted, and we have been left with radio silence since then in both the patch note and dev log channels since the time I post this, three months later. 
In my opinion, I believe the devs have treated the early access release of LWitW as a full-pricetag demo, with the wavering promise of a finished game in the future, that is why I also believe we have to jump through the unnecessary hoop of opting in to a beta on an already early access game to see the one small content update we've been given,
and though they have stated they plan to release the game in 2023 it's been shown that the game records are being updated in Steamdb, I can't in good conscience suggest this game to any of my friends in its current state, and I feel most of the people on this server share in my frustration.

To any and all people interested in purchasing this game, I hope this post has added clarity to your decision. 
To the people that purchased this game and hope for a finished product, I hope you continue to let your voice be heard and we hopefully reach the devs.
And to SUNNY SIDE UP  and the team working on this game, I hope you understand these criticisms come from a place of love for LWitW, and our desire to see the finished game and know it is not abandoned, as was the anniversary of it's early access release on May 16th past. 
Thank you for reading

Also starting the day at 10AM I find makes the days quite short, maybe start the day a little earlier? 138121579.review:
A cute little game that honestly reminds me of playing old-school collect-n-craft type games (except this is much more visually appealing). 
It is in early access, so that will effect my overall stance on the game.

Pros: 
* As I said, really cute art style, it's really what drew me into this game and I was always looking forward to anything new just so I could admire how pretty it is.
* Ellie (our main character) is very charming, and I found her boundless optimism- but not naivety- refreshing in a protagonist. Honestly, I'm just glad they gave her a personality at all. so many of these relaxing simulator games feel a bit unnerving because of the dead-eyed protagonist, but not this one! 
* The music is pleasant to listen to, and the sound effects are high quality but not jarring, so don't forget to turn up the volume.
* The quest log was nice, I especially liked how it showed you the exact character you needed to go to next, just in case you didn't feel like running around going through every characters every dialogue.

Cons:
* Too short! I want to play more, but I finished the main story in about 6 hours, I could have done it faster too, but I was taking my time with it. This one can be forgiving because of the whole 'early access' thing, so it wasn't unexpected, but I was hoping for just a little bit more for 16 USD. 
* there were a few moderately bad audio bugs (music stuttering and sounds being 'staticky'), and a lot of visual errors on some characters (fox kid I'm looking at you).
* it can be a bit tedious at times, like seriously the prices on some of the upgrades are ridiculous and there's no way I'm spending that much time grinding to make money and resources for barely any improvement. the only upgrade that was actually useful was the first extractor upgrade and inventory and that's it, everything else is a waste of time because the cost far outweighs the reward (compounding the "why bother" mentality is the short playtime (again)).
* you can buy books from the merchant, one of them is in Korean, just a heads up.

Overall this is an adorable game with a lot of potential, which is currently being bogged down with its somewhat tedious gameplay loop and useless 'rewards'. However, it's still present and relacing experience that I genuinely enjoyed.  I really am looking forward to where this is going! There are not enough cozy witch games in the world. 😊 7.3/10

136659015.review:
I bought this game today and played for 6 hours straight w/o getting up, so safe to say I enjoy the game!

please keep in mind the game is still very much in development while I am writing this so not all features that may be present in the future may be in my game currently as of writing this, this is also true for any issues I bring up currently- they may be resolved; with that said here's my review.

This game overall is very much down my alley, considering I'm also an avid player of stardew and potion permit, though if you like the character customisation aspect, that isn't present here- In LWITW (Little Witch In The Woods) you play as Ellie a kid straight from school headed to Highlion for her apprenticeship, events occur and she ends up getting off the train and finding her self staying near Wisteria.

Plot-wise there is an interesting story to be followed here & my only current complaint is that it feels short (but again, I'm writing this during development so there is hopefully more to come!)

Art Style, it is pixel art as seen in all the promo videos and pictures, all the characters and landscaping are very well designed and give a very beautiful fantasy-esc vibe to the over all game.

Dialog, each character is quite clearly given a personality that shines through, though currently some of the dialog is hard to read or has a grammatical error or two (this is very much some dialog, the majority that I've encountered so fact is completely fine)

Creativity, if you're like me and need to constantly be going "Oooo & Aaaaah" at everything, the game has great little potions, creatures and plants to find and document in your diary, not to mention the designs of the village folk being certainly eye-catching.

controls, in the game you don't use the traditional WASD keys to move but the arrow keys, which initially threw me off but i started getting the hang of it- though what was a little more unconventional was some of the other keys for things and the complete lack of use of the mouse- you are also not (not that i could see anyways) capable of changing the controls.

My main "issue" with the game currently is that there isn't enough of the game (which in my opinion is the best critique). It just feels slightly short to have gotten as far as I have in 6 hours (not speed running btw, mainly just running around picking up random stuff and getting used to the map). Again this is most likely going to be resolved with time as more content is added and the game in developed.

final thoughts?
As the opening line said, I sat for 6 hours straight playing the game and liked it, its an interesting little game that I would recommend if you like games similar to the ones mentioned above, the interaction between characters & the overall layout is great and I hope to only see this game blossom as it further grows and develops :)

136387328.review:
I’ve been so hyped for this game ever since I saw it on Wholesome Games and was eager to try it.

I have a massive backlog of games, so I finally tried it in April 2023 in early access. The game is super cute and fun, and I thought it would be the entire game, but what you have access to is pretty short. It only took me a few days to “finish.” It also doesn’t take long to get used to the controls (I played using a controller). The characters, setting, and story draw you in. I was saddened that I completed the first part of the game/story, but I’m still able to farm to make monies and upgrade things..but it feels unfinished.

After I finished the first part and complained to my bf about the short story, I stumbled upon beta, and guys, it’s such an improvement! You can tell the devs are working hard on the game. The new features available in beta make more sense and..quality of life update..yes!!! 

In regular early access, what you see is what you get in terms of gathering. However, in beta, there are shiny/unique versions of items that give you a chance to get more than one item on a pull. Plus, there are newer quests and home improvements/decor that I’m excited about. I can’t wait for more content! It’s such a cute and casual wholesome game. I enjoyed it, and I think you will too!

Also, I can’t wait to learn what’s happening with our candy friend.

Really cute and sweet cozy witchy game! The controls are a little odd-- with the action button/choosing dialogue being "z" and not "e", the movement being arrow keys and not the standard WASD, the inventory as "s" and not "i", the encyclopedia being "d" (maybe for dictionary), and a few other controls that took me a while to get used to. 136003985.review: This cute game is visually appealing and story driven. Its calming with an enchanting soundtrack and not real pressures to finish tasks in any sort of time frame. The time clock and days do pass but it never felt like I was running behind schedule like I felt with games like Stardew. In addition there were no significant consequences to not getting back to bed before you pass out (12am). It was an endearing story, which is yet unfinished. I enjoyed learning about the village and the characters within. Everything you need for tasks are available around you. I did notice that there was at least one side quest post beta game completion (as noted with a thank you screen). There is the option to continue after the main quest. You can continue to make potions and candies which allow you to make money or potentially solve situations that will come in the future.  I hope to see this game find its completion as I would love to learn the complete story of this village, the villagers, the main character, and the other more mysterious characters we met or have yet to met. I think for its price tag it is reasonable especially with the story to be expanding. Just know that the controls are not typical and can take a bit to get used to (Z= Action | Movement = arrow keys | S= supplies/Inventory | D = Dictionary | A = Use spells | E/R = Cycle Potions/ stir direction for making potions| Q/W = Cycling tools/ Heat for potion creations - Note these do not cause issue for having different functions).

134951002.review:
A fun little game; the little witch is cute and fun, so are the NPC, the land is charming with a lot of flora and quirky animals that you get your crafting ingredients from in various ways. 
You get a main guest (or rather series of quests) to rebuild the village, with side quests with the villagers, and crafting potions for sale to get money (in two different currencies).

It is quite short at the moment (early access), I assume by the time the game is fully released it will be a lot longer and the story complete. Though some ingredients are already hard enough to get (mandrake, terrier hair), so I hope there won't be more difficult ones and/or the need for vast amount of them...

I encountered only one bug, when closing the game it stuck on the screen with the train, I had to force quit. The save worked OK though.

BUT the major problem in this game are [b]the controls[/b]. 
It is keyboard only, which I wouldn't mind [i]per se[/i] except :
-- the chosen keys make absolutely no sense; why oh why does the inventory open with S, and the encyclopedia with D ?!?
-- The game never identified / took into account that I'm not using a QWERTY keyboard, so each time it was "use Z" I had to press W, and A instead of Q, and so on; it made the system even more confusing.
Both could be resolved if there was an option to change the keys to what we are confortable with, but there isn't.

Also, I feel the storage system is a bit off, considering the number of different ingredients and that we can have only 10 in one slot. Often time I was on a collecting expedition but had to go home at 2 or 3 PM because I couldn't pick anything more. And extending storage, both in the backpack and the coffers in the craft room, is crazy expensive. 
So it adds grind and frustation to the collecting of ingredients, which otherwise wouldn't be so bad, more like a peaceful stroll in a beautiful day.

134345730.review:
At present, this game is decent. It's reasonably optimized, although it does have some rough spots here and there, and the content is fleshed out pretty well. However, in my opinion, it lacks more main content and a more robust gameplay loop. Since it's an early access game, it's understandable that it's still lacking, but it's worth noting nonetheless. 

The game would benefit from quality of life changes such as better pathing, player hitbox, more durable broom, and improved NPC interactions. 

One of the changes I hope to see is a more complex potion crafting system. Currently, it's okay, but I would like to see more intricate recipes added later on or perhaps multi-step recipes.

Overall, I'd give this game a 9 out of 10. It's a fairly fleshed out game that simply needs more time and devotion to become a great 10 out of 10 game.

133773699.review:
Ok, there's good and bad to this game. Honestly I like this Little Witch game but a lot needs to be ironed out through further development. 

Good things first: The game is absolutely adorable. I LOVE the art style and animations and the music is cute and soothing too. Although things can get a little repetitive it honestly doesn't feel boring and the crafting/potion making system is fun and simple enough to learn. Love that you don't lose items if you mix a potion wrong either. I think the overall story-line is good and I'm excited to see where it goes and if we can travel to other destinations via the train eventually. I think that would be fun. I also like all the characters and critters so far, they're all very cute, I'd love some plushies or merch of them. I also never had any bugs where I got stuck or lost a save or anything.

The Bad: The controls are absolute trash. They do have controller support...but that sucks too. Nothing really makes sense and it's frustrating that you can't remap keys/buttons. Really need that implemented ASAP.  As some others said you get used to it but that's just because you HAVE to if you want to do anything in game. It never really feels intuitive or comfortable. (I get that it's early access but the mapping just doesn't feel comfortable from the start) The writing for cut scenes is way too much and kind of annoying, especially the train scene in the beginning of the game when you really want to jump in and explore. And especially when Ellie is talking to her hat. I have skipped multiple dialogues and not missed anything at all. 

All in all I DO think this game is super cute and fun to play baring some of the dialogue and beginning train scene. I think anyone would have fun with Little Witch. If the devs let us remap buttons to make more sense, and cut down on the unimportant dialogue this will be an awesome and cute game.

133688508.review: Adorable game. However bugs reported for 4+ months are blocking further progress.

133650507.review:
I bought this bc I wanted something similar to Animal Crossing, which isn't available on PC. This is a very cute, relaxing, and fun game that gives a similar feeling, and I'm really looking forward to all the rest of the content. 3.5 hours in I've mostly spent my time running around to make potions and collect ingredients.

I believe you will be able to have furniture and arrange it later on in the game? So that'll be a great aspect to add too besides just the farming-type content.

My one complaint so far is that the broom is a little annoying to control because it accelerates, so it's easy to bump into trees/bushes when trying to steer, but that's a very minor detail. It also has low durability. However, when more of the map opens up, it may become more important. 

I would also like a button to instantly teleport back to the house for example, so you don't have to fly/run all the way back, which can be time consuming. Or portals to let you go to specific regions without having to run.

Regardless, I definitely recommend this for a great relaxing game! :)

EXTREMELY fun and cute game! Please keep in mind - this game is still in early access. If you're not sure what that means, please inform yourself before purchasing. The dev is super open about progress, which is a huge plus! They just released some notes earlier this month (Feb 2023) so I'm not sure why some people are griping about no updates. There were a few months of a break, but that is to be expected during the Winter with so many holidays going on! The dev has always been active on social media even before EA release and continues to be. 

The text is a little clunky, but it's easy to understand and tbh I couldn't do any better writing a game in several languages at a time. It's not inhibiting to gameplay at all.
I feel like all of the puzzles/potions/ingredients are straightforward and intuitive. This game should be pretty easy even for someone without history playing similar video games. 
The music is so cute, and the sound fx from interacting with things are top tier!
I honestly have nothing negative to add, which in a way is unhelpful, I know. But I just wanted to add my vote to the "please buy this!" pool. :) Whether it's now during EA/Open Beta or later when the game is fully finished, this game is excellent and made by a wonderful developer!

132299719.review:
I have to post this here because for some reason I can't comment directly through the Steam Launcher, so I hope this goes through, it's feedback if the developer happens to see this


Very cute, and so far a lot calm, exploring and puzzle fun. Sometimes the controls are a little confusing. Like, when moving things from my chest to inventory, I naturally try to use the arrow keys to move between those spaces and grab what I need, getting confused as to why I can't before I realise I need to hit the TAB button to get from my pack to the chest and back again. Making potions took a bit of getting used to mainly because of the heat sensor. There's 3 little flames to indicate the hottest setting, so for some reason I thought that was setting number three before realising that, when it asks you to set it to heat 1, 2, 3, 4, or 5, it was talking about each notch on the heat detector. Easy to figure out that one and not ingredients were lost the first time I screwed it up, but numbers on those notches would help get it the first time.

You also have to use odd keyboard controls to make it work. Press Q or W to make the heat go back and forth while using E or R to stir left, not stir, or stir right. I feel like that could be simplified by just letting me use the arrow keys to scroll over the potion menu and using the Z or ENTER button to select what I want, or even a mouse option to click on those controls. Luckily those controls are written at the bottom of the screen every time, so I can always see what to do, even though I'm always looking down because I can never remember off the top of my head. It's a mild complaint, but it feels like switching that up could make menu navigating a little more streamlined and user friendly. 

Also, the "hit" detection is a little off at times. Sometimes I can be right on top of something that's grabbable, with the little arrow above it, and the Z button won't quite work. I have to move around a little to get what I need. Also not a big deal because it's still pretty close on and I don't have to wiggle around much to get what I want, but it happens enough that I notice it. Sometimes to go back I'll also hit the esc button out of habit before realising the game wants me to press Z or X instead, including on the front menu screen where the train is rolling by, and the save screen. I'll press ENTER over the save option before remembering I need to hit Z.

It's all nitpicky stuff so far, but the game looks pretty polished with the exception of a few minor places, so until I find something else you almost have to be nitpicky, but it would be nice and let me fall into this game easier if these were addressed. Otherwise, beautiful game. When there is music, it's soft and fits the tone, I wish there was more of it. I might be too early in, but I noticed some spots that sounded a little empty with the exception of train sounds or pages flipping the first time I was in the Witch's workshop. Beautiful, pleasant music when it is there, though, and the graphics are adorable. I love watching Ellie running around in her little chibi pixel art, and THANK YOU for making the run option with the Space bar. I played another game where running was SHIFT and I didn't realize how much I needed the space bar until I played that game. Ellie running with the Space Bar control is so much more comfortable for my hand. And the little flowers everywhere, the birds, the fox, and even the grass all are just precious. I'll definitely be playing more of this and so far, as early access, this was worth it to buy so I'd love to watch it improve

131777820.review:
This game, despite its faults, was very fun for me. Lets do a quick, spoiler free, pros and cons list.

Pros: 
- VERY cute pixel art style! It consitent and really really well done. 
- Dreamy OST that fits the game very well
- Simple, but enjoyable gameplay
- Charming characters that are fun to talk to and have wonderful personalities
- Good story imo! I was quite intrigued the whole way through
 
Cons:
- Definitely an early access game, that's for sure. Mild bugs but nothing game breaking that I experienced
- Control scheme uses keyboard exclusively. Works just fine, just takes a lot of getting used to. After playing the whole game through I still wasn't really used to it til the very end, and even then, not really.
- Somewhat Repetitive gameplay loop with gathering ingredients. Especially early game ones (looking at you, maple herb)
- Limited OST. Just a handful of songs. Good ones! But they are all pretty short as well.
- Some of the writing (characters speaking to one another, etc) does not flow well. Some grammar and spacing errors, but more than that it feels like characters aren't exactly talking to one another? Just sorta, saying things out loud in each others presence if that makes sense. They lose their personality sometimes which is a shame.
- A map feature would be very very welcome, but there isn't one at the time of writing.
- Crafting takes quite a while. Upgrading your tools essentially just lets you craft one more item at a time per upgrade, and upgrades get expensive very quickly. Upgrading doesn't let you craft new things or anything, like how I assume it would when I started. It became worth the upgrades *just* to skip the "jump hip hip hooray!" animation every time you make a potion.
- Due to early access, some items will be useless and not worth collecting, even at the current endgame

Overall I still think the game is worth it. I see many people "want" to give it a positive review but currently cannot due to the games state of completion and the like. But I think people know what they're paying for here. It's not a terribly expensive game either, and I doubt the price will change when the game is complete.

131728290.review: I wanted to like this game as the artwork is so adorable and the main character is so cute. And the whole premise is right up my street. However i didn't even make it half an hour in because the control keys are terrrible, and are NOT the typical WSAD and the interact key is Z instead of the typical E or left click of a mouse. It was just so clunky and difficult to use for me. I had to request a refund. Maybe if they ever add the option to change the controls i'll purchase again, but that was a deal breaker for me.

131657486.review:
Definitely feels like early access. Like many others have mentioned, the dialogue is very clunky, and there are many grammatical and spelling mistakes. Personally, I also feel like there is WAY too much dialogue, especially for repeated interactions. I lost interest in the story very quickly, as I didn't want to read through any of it. The dialogue menus for shopkeepers especially are also a bit confusing and unnecessarily complex. I had some brief trouble figuring out how to fill potion orders, because it is a separate option from selling potions in a completely different part of the dialogue menu. 

The gameplay itself is decent enough, although it still has some issues. One of the most notable problems is that the notebook doesn't always open when you press the control (D), although it usually fixes itself if you open one of the other overlays first. I also really dislike the stamina system, as it isn't super intuitive and can leave you stranded in the middle of the woods unable to pick fruit to replenish it, forcing you to return to the witch hut at the pace of a snail (unless you have fuel in your broom). This makes the process of gathering ingredients, which is already a very repetitive aspect, that much more irritating. 

I found the level of guidance/handholding at the beginning to be a bit odd. There is little to no introduction to the controls (which are by no means standard or intuitive). However, it also feels a bit restrictive in terms of how much exploration it lets you do on your own to start. I found myself discovering areas and figuring out puzzles before I was meant to, and then still having to go find the necessary dialogue before I was allowed to progress. Then later on, the game begins to feel a bit stagnant as you are just left to grind for money to upgrade/buy things. 

If there's one good thing about this game, it's the environment. All of the areas have a comfortable amount of detail, and the pixel art is well done. The plants and creatures are interesting, unique, and fun to interact with. I think with more time and care put into the rest of the game, it could turn out to be decent. However, as it is right now, I don't think it's worth even the reduced early access price. Although it's playable, it feels half-finished.

I really loved this game. Would recommend playing in the beta version as it has a lot of QoL features and more content. 
I've played 28.8 hours 9 of which were in the Early Access before switching over to the beta. 

I don't usually leave reviews, but I've enjoyed myself immensely in this little world and my only qualm is that it isn't bigger and have more creatures and things in it. 
As for core gameplay aspects-
I completed all of the encyclopedia tasks in the beta and upgraded my storage to max, even after the end of the main quests the game continues to be charming and lovely. It's nice to just hang out with. I look forward to playing it a third time when the full release comes out. I could spend forever in this game maxing out everything with how much I enjoy wandering around the world, collecting materials and interacting with the characters. 

When it comes to characterization, Ellie and her hat have such a cute dynamic. I wish we knew more about them from before Little Witch in the Woods. I'd play a game about her in Witch School and hope in the final release that we actually get to go to Highlion- or that they make another game where we get to go there. I want to explore more areas in the world and interact with more creatures. Everyone is so charming and the pixel art style (both in game and in the portraits) is super cute and I hope we learn more about them in future updates. 

I cannot praise this game enough- if you're thinking about picking it up, please do. One of the most pleasant and relaxing experiences I've had with a game to date.

I got the game soon after it released since I had been pretty excited for it for a while being a lover of cozy and cutesy exploration type games. When I first started playing, i ended up putting the game away 2 hours in and didn't touch it for a while. The main reason is I was getting absolutely drowned in dialogue and for a good chunk of those 2 hours i felt like i was watching a movie that every now and then gave me the option to actually stop and play the game as well as uncover the story for myself. I came back to it recently and honestly I'm glad I gave it a shot because just a bit further and I was put into environment I wanted in a game. I explored, learnt things myself without a guide, interacted with the town and from time to time listened in to the bickering between the main characters. The inclusion of little side quests that force you to always be stacked up on items and the selling/buying system made me really happy to indulge in. I felt like I was exploring for a reason and i was a part of the world outside of just the main quest. 

With that being said there are a few little things that do bother me, mainly the controls on keyboard. If you're someone that finds it hard to adhere to new controls like me, you may want to consider connecting a controller instead. I wish there was an option to change your keybinds to fit everyone's personal needs and comfort. With the point that I am in the game, some characters also feel rather bland, and sometimes dialogue feels unnecessarily long and repetitive.

Overall its a great game. I would 100% recommend trying it out if you like games like stardew valley or cozy grove.

129604081.review:
This game is exactly what I have been needing for a while: pixel, cute, and witchy. However, you can tell this game is not finished and there are some bugs to work out. Here are some of my thoughts after playing the early release version. 

Dialogue: 
Like most games in this genre there is a lot of dialogue, especially at the start on the train (as others have mentioned). There were some translation issues, so carefully reviewing and condensing the dialogue for the English version would be great. 

More specifically the dialogue controls and options could be smoothed out. You currently have three options at the start "personal stories", "chit-chat", and "shop options." I think the personal stories and chit chat option can be condensed into one option. The reason is because you also have to open special dialogue about certain topics and it starts to get a bit cluttered. You use these options to get more information about the world and important hints about side quests. You acquire "key phrases" that you can use with other players to get more information. Sometimes this information opens up the side quest option (by hitting tab) and other times it does not. It might be nice for players to have a section in the journal that logs these key phrases as the game gets longer. For the demo it was okay because you have limited people you can speak with about these key phrases, but if the game play gets longer and there are a lot more characters this might be useful to add. It would just be a section in the journal that recaps the convo, highlights the key phrase in red text, and then the person you need to speak with also in red text.  I have seen this mechanism in other games. 

Controls: 
The controls are a bit cumbersome using the keyboard (I did not try with a controller) and can probably be simplified. Mostly the issue was selecting and using items from the inventory. Perhaps the coding can be improved in the later versions of the game. Currently, you have to hit several keys in order to use an item (ex: hit S to open inventory, then Z to select, then Z again to equip, then A to put in your hand, then Z to target, then C to throw a potion at a plant). For me, it did not make the gameplay more immersive and I found it a bit clunky. Perhaps after you equip the item the controls can be simplified to autotarget nearby objects (ex: plants) just like how the feather pen works and then just hit Z again to throw/use a potion.

I liked the how the cauldron controls are done. You add ingredients, select heat level, and what direction you need to stir. That is a pretty fun and cute experience.  It might be nice to add a window when using the cauldron where you can have your selected potion or candy recipe up at the same time underneath the ingredients window. Right now, you have to open the book to check your recipes, then go to the cauldron. This is a minor point. 

Pricing of items: 
As some others have mentioned a lot of the items are very pricey for the game. It does force you to go collect items and build your inventory in order to make potions/candies to sell for gold or luna coins. Then you can buy items or upgrades for the village or your workshop. However, the prices are a bit steep in my opinion. As others have mentioned you have a limited amount of resources that spawn in the game per day. So you will have days that you are just waiting for items to respawn to collect, then extract/roast, and then brew in order to get to the next step. While collecting resources and crafting items is a main feature these games, it can get pretty repetitive. Some of this can currently be bypassed by purchasing resources (sticks, rocks, etc) using your gold in the village. Currently, you cannot buy potion/candy ingredients for from Diane which would be helpful. You also get a very low price for selling potions/candy even when you do the special delivery option (only available once per day). This really ends up being the only option as selling the potions or candy without the special delivery option have very low prices. Therefore, a lot of your game play time is spent collecting items to get enough money to move forward. Some people might say this adds to the games experience, but I think there is a balance in how much time you spend collecting these items and the payoff you get for doing it. I would solve this problem by doing one of the following 1) decrease the price of upgrades and blueprints 2) increase the value of selling potions/candy for both the regular and special delivery options 3) Make the upgrades to the extractor, cauldron, etc to yield more products at the start rather than just allow the player to extract 2x extractions at a time (this was not worth the price of the upgrade).

Overall: 
That all said, I really liked the game and enjoyed playing. The premise of the game is everything I have been wanting for a while. I think the finished version of the game has a lot of promise. The story is very charming and I would love to play the final version when it is available!

There are points where you'll read characters talking for a bit, pick up something, and then they talk even more. I think the game is going for more story than a lot of crafting simulations do, but I think it could be balanced a bit more. Tutorials are super important but I shouldn't be sitting there wondering when I'll even get to play the game or if i have to wait just a bit longer for characters to finish explaining a mechanic or world-building. 

A good example of the dialogue being a bit intrusive is early on in the game you're shown a new area, but you need to be back to a train by morning. Its 10pm, so morning is far aways off, but your witch hat will bug you about being late every 30 seconds or so. I get that i can explore later but i never felt like i should be hurrying. I feel like instead of a pop-up dialog , something like an arrow could have worked, or just simply a note somewhere to remind you of your task. Small things like that would help the game flow between story and game-play a bit better.  The story itself is great, there are just moments where it feels like it drags on slightly too long or pops up too frequently, if that makes sense. 

So right now we have a game where the story is good, and the gameplay itself is promising, it just doesn't know when to let the player just play and have fun, and when to sit the player down and go off about the world and its stories. I wouldn't call it boring, but there are times i wish i could do more things. I have a feeling this does get better once the world is explained and you unlock more game mechanics, but i wish there was more balance.

129159683.review:
As is, this game is incomplete -- consider it [b]an extended demo[/b] with about 6-10 hrs of content in its current state. Still, I enjoyed Little Witch in the Woods very much; it scratches the Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing itch very well. Really looking forward to the final release. I hope the dev team considers all the feedback from early access players and their Discord to make the game even better!

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
    [*][b]Art and design:[/b] The art style is adorable, with a wide range of expressions and animations. Unique character designs and sprites. I love watching Ellie run or ride her broomstick around the woods! The critters are also really cute. The team working on this game has put so much thought and care into their worldbuilding, environment, and game design - it doesn't feel like it's trying to copy Stardew, like many other games in this genre. Little Witch in the Woods has a style and feeling unique to itself, and I love that.
    [*][b]Gameplay:[/b] It's honestly really fun and relaxing to run around and gather materials, brew potions and candies, and fulfill quests. The mechanics are refreshing and unlike other games - this isn't a farming sim or a townbuilding sim. Though it's very simple and can get repetitive, I enjoy the gameplay cycle of going around the village every day to see if anyone needs my help, and becoming more familiar with the world by exploring. 
    [*][b]Controller support:[/b] This game is best enjoyed on a controller, imo. I played it entirely on controller and had a seamless experience - not entirely sure how it feels to play this with a mouse and keyboard, but other reviewers say it's less enjoyable since you can't rebind your keys. 
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
    [*][b]Boring dialogue:[/b] There's a limited number of scripted lines, which get repetitive and boring to run through. As others have mentioned, the intro to the game on the train is a bit long and boring. I don't mind the banter between Virgil and Ellie, as I think it's fun, but I can see how others could find it hard to get through. I do get a bit tired of the small talk chitchat between Ellie and some of the villagers.  
[*][b]Early access[/b]: Because it's in early access, the game is definitely incomplete and there's not enough to do, or there are things in the game that serve no purpose yet/lead to dead ends, i.e. the "Shop" option doesn't do anything for Rubrum, Roy or Entie. There are also a number of bugs, like Rubrum disappearing randomly, and quality of life issues like no save slots, expensive upgrades with no way to track in your jounral what resources are needed for those upgrades, and the limited number of resources you can gather each day vs. the number required for recipes (ex: the world only spawns 3 PomPoms each day, but you need 4 pompom feathers to create one ingredient for recipes). However, the dev team is diligently working on updates and adding new features for the final release, so I'm really looking forward to those. 
 [*][b]Localization issues[/b]: I was able to tell within the first 5 min of gameplay that this game was originally developed for a Korean audience, which doesn't bother me that much since I can speak Korean and can get the gist of what the original lines might have said. However, some of the dialogue is really awkwardly or inconsistently translated, and in some cases where you have reply options, the English gets cut off in those boxes so you can't even see what the full sentence says. The only option for reporting these translation issues currently is via their Discord server.
    [*][b]Price:[/b] I received this game as a gift from a friend, but I wouldn't pay full price for it currently. There's just not enough content and polish to consider it a full game - so you won't really get your money's worth unless you're trying to support the devs and buy in early to avoid the price hike when it gets a full release.
[/list]

In its current state, it's an 7/10 for me, but I could see it easily getting a 9 or 10 when it's complete... which could easily take a year or two in my opinion. But I'm eagerly awaiting the final product, and cheering on the team while they work.

Cute game! Enough grammatical and mechanical writing errors to convince me that the game creator is not a native English speaker; there are definitely some sentences that do not parse, or translate well. Recommendations: 1) English-speaking editor. 2) Use of mouse for navigation or interaction, as well as standard WASD direction keys. 3) Simplified NPC interactions -- it takes too long to cycle through all their lines to get OUT of interacting with them. 4) Please, please, please cut out all the boredom on the train... it's excruciating. 5) Have a journal or notebook where upgrade requirements can be kept, so players can keep track of what they need to gather/earn. 6) Allow players to access inventory from within interactions with NPCs -- e.g. if player is told the purchase of an item costs so much, allow players to see funds available to them; or if player attempts an upgrade, give a specific message about what, exactly, is missing, if player does not have all items required.

I look forward to seeing what you're able to do with the game!

127578374.review:
Early Access Review (will update after full release). First off, this is not a farm sim where you create a character and do Stardew-type things. This is the very specific story of Ellie, a witch apprentice, who has to figure out witch life in the forest. There is some collecting you will do for potions, currency to earn to unlock additional recipes and purchase ingredients, but so far it's all staying closely connected to the story.  Which isn't a bad thing!  Sometimes you just want a cute pixel art story game with not-to-difficult puzzles. 

With only about 5-6 hours released of a (currently planned) 20-hour game available, I can't comment too much about the full story; however, the pixel art is gorgeous, music is well done and nice to have in the background, movement is smooth, and tool use is easy to get the hang of quickly.  The one drawback for me is the dialogue, which can be circular/repetitive at times and appears on the screen a bit too slow. I find I keep clicking to try to make it appear faster and sometimes it just really doesn't, which can be tedious after a while. It's also a bit more juvenile than I expected in parts, for Ellie and a few others, but maybe that's because one of the characters is a literal kid. Since there's a lot of feedback regarding this, I'm hopeful the devs address dialogue content and speed as they work on various updates. 

Overall, I'm happy with the game as I've seen it so far, and look forward to playing the full release as Ellie tries to help her forest friends, meets new people, gets to use more potions, and has more dynamic interactions.

Incredibly relaxing game with cute and witty story.

127354462.review:
I was gifted Little Witch in the Woods by a friend after we discovered the main heroine's name was Ellie! How could I not play a game with someone who shared my namesake? Soon after I was absolutely obsessed with the game. I started out strong and played non stop for a few days before I fell off as many others do. However, I more recently with the update and beta options decided to try again, as I'd been waiting patiently for the full release.

The new beta version was so much better! It even worked great on the steam deck with some adjustments. Overall the game is an adorable little adventure about a witch who can't stand boredom, and her calling towards a village in desperate need of help. After an incident created by her own desire for adventure, Ellie finds herself trying to save a nearby village after it's destruction left it almost abandoned. Taking it upon herself to find a way to bring the village back to it's original glory, she decides to set out and get her hands dirty to do the job.

The story so far is adorable and warm and sweet. It was sometimes difficult to find the proper way to gather materials and prepare them for both requests and exploring, but I soon found that upgrading my equipment and keeping a stock pile of the more common ingredients was a huge help. Gathering things was always fun, though somewhat frustrating when I didn't realize the easier way to gather materials. Some of the potions and parts of the encyclopedia weren't exactly clear on how to properly gather materials. Pom Pom Feathers and Smile Bubble's were particularly hard for me to figure out how to gather them efficiently. After trial and error and some research I was able to find an efficient way to gather them, but I do wish there would have been a way to gather hints or something in regards to the uses of potions. 

I did find certain parts of my day in game upsetting, but that was less an issue with the game, and more that I wanted to have more time in the day to do things before the curfew hit. I couldn't help but want to squeeze every bit of time allowed to search for new and cooler things and ingredients. Sometimes I found myself growing sad that I was finishing up a story point, unsure when I'd fully be without another goal. I didn't want the story to end! And just being the early release version of the game, to have me sad the rest is still to come is a definite positive to me. 

Altogether if you like story driven indie style simulation games then you're in for a treat. Aside from having an intriguing story that has yet to be finished (as of this review at least), Little Witch in the Woods has beautiful scenery, fun exploration mechanics, and a cast of characters that both make me laugh and smile. It's an amazing game that I only happened to find due to the heroine having a matching name. And honestly, I am more than glad to share my name with our little witch.

126947125.review:
I started playing this because the gameplay looked similar to Stardew Valley, which is my favorite game in this genre. With that being said, if you're looking for a game similar to Stardew, this is similar with some major differences. Keep in mind that this is alpha so things might change, but here were the key takeaways I have after finishing all available content so far:
1) It is not a farming simulator. You forage for everything and you make potions and other witchling things with the stuff you gather. It looks like tools will come later, but so far you have gloves, a bug net, and a quill (for building your encyclopedia).
2) You don't change the layout of your land or build buildings (except story-gated ones in the nearby village). There is no customization with placement. 
3) You already start off with all the apparatuses you need in your home - you have the ability to upgrade them.
4) It is heavy in story. It doesn't just drop you off at your location and say good luck -- it takes you through cutscenes, dialogue, etc.

With that being said, I do like it. It's easy to get the hang of. I'll probably play the full version once it's out. But it's not a "grow your own herbs" and chill thing, and there was more dialogue than I would have liked. There is a puzzle aspect to it too, which I enjoyed. My least favorite aspect was that the foraging made me feel like I was racing against the clock to get any story done (seemed like a 10 minute in-game timer to every 20 seconds or so - you wake up at 8am and you pass out at midnight with a repercussion of sleeping in until 10am with an energy deficit the next day).

126790694.review:
This game has a lot of good components - I like the characters, art, music, and story! Such great ideas with magic and nature and adventuring in the woods. But the early promise of an epic adventure game rather quickly quickly nose-dives into a tedious and monotonous linear task-driven gameplay that is more like a boring job than a game. A couple of days in, the tasks on my list don't have much point or payoff. The puzzles are easy; potion-making moves the linear plot forward one very small step at a time. I'm bored. There's a lot of complaints about the dialogue, but it's easy to skip and that's not the worst problem for me by far.

I was on the fence of whether I should write a review or not, as I've played a couple (baffling?) "games" this year that just didn't feel like games to me, and this might just be a (new to me) genre I don't like. Stardew Valley is dull, an adventure game minus the adventure. There's a game about unpacking, no joke, and it's popular (?!?). Ultimately, I paid for this game due to overwhelmingly positive reviews, so I think it's only fair if I'm honest about my disappointment.

The team who developed this game is clearly incredibly talented. I'm positive that the people who created this is fully capable of writing a slightly better story. Add some tweaks to the gameplay - way more adventure and way less pointless tasks - and this could be a great game. But if they intend it to play as-is, it's a style of game I hope to avoid in the future.

126290852.review:
So, it all began with me trying to find a relaxing game with none violence genre, where it was only you and there was no time limit. That's when I saw this game, little witch in the woods!

Now, the first thing that came in mind was that it was a cute, pixel graphic game. There already are plenty of cute, pixel graphic game out there on the internet, but what this game has isn't in aany other cute, pixel graphic games. It had passion in it, the animations that are made with the pixel-graphic made sense, the creators had really put a big thought to link the accurately movment to the pixels. All the other pixel games that I have made never had this.

When it comes to the gameplay and the story, it's basically on a different level from the games that I have played. There is this normal system, which is the wuest system. There is main quest, which you do to continue the story, the character quest or as I like to call it "sub stories", which is smaller quest that tells us about all the character in the game, and lastly there is the delivery task, which is just for money. Sadly, when it comes to the main quest and the "sub stories" you won't receive any rewards when completning the quest, but it may or may not be added in the fully release. But the quest ain't just for the rewards, it is mainly for the satisfaing story.

The story and the character build is also facsinating. Usually in any other games they tends to do only an easy character build and then focus on the main story, some also focus on the character stories. Now, this game has really done well with the character design and their build, which is rare in my case. I was trying to look for a game where there was fantasy, which a great gameplay and also where the character were made with the devs heart and mind. This game has it. They really thought about all the character, gave them specific roles in the game and the story.

I am hoping that this game will soon gets it full release in the future. I really want to see what more they add and I gladly will recommend this game to others.

10/10

I know I have very little game time to write a thorough review about game mechanics and other game-play related content, but I have to say that the main reason I don't progress further is because of the dialog.
