Every few minutes or entering a new area, ensues long dialog that serves little purpose, aside from consuming time, like the introduction dialog of the game: one minute in and I was already skipping it so I could gain control of the character as fast as possible. Aside from that, the graphics are really nice, the color palette is also very well thought, and in general it has a very cohesive vibe. 125164084.review:
[b]TL;DR[/b] MTL'd with syntax correction little adventure game with potion making and day-to-day game-loop with the cutest animations and the most unique witch. Too many "hold button" to act, though. Lots of potential already realized, but held back.

Saying that the game's english translation leaves to be desired is an understatement. You can understand the flow of things, but the amount of oddities and the frequency of them are enough to muddle things. You'll hear people say "you can speak comfortably" all the time, and the book with the recipes will have stuff like "Stir the ladle don't stir" to tell you the stiring direction, which, depending on where you look, might change from "Clockwise" to "right". It's easy to tell the developers have little grasp on english. If you can forgive that, the rest of the game can be a flip of a coin.

Day and night cycles changing behaviour of fauna and flora, different ways to interact with the fauna and flora yielding different results... mechanics wise, it's quite a treat. Then you have to deal with "hold" prompts on situations where you shouldn't need ALL THE TIME (it's not about situations that are irreversible and critical, or are going to put you into a fixed cutscene that will take a whole minute), no way of doing processing resources or making potions in batches (at least with un-upgraded gear), and things to upgrade that don't tell you nothing about what will change with the upgrade. There is promise, but lack of QoL and excesive use of hold prompts is a pain.

Animations, art and characters wise, it's awesome. The main character is funny as heck, as non-standard as you can get, being the kind of person that might light something on fire if she has the slightest belief that it will burn in a strage color. The animations are cute and funny, characterizing everything so well. Ellie is love, Ellie is life.

It kinda hurts me to give a negative review, but this game is basically one decent translation review and one QoL pass away from being the best thing you'll have in terms of a short and sweet, cute and funny potion making game ever. The base for the game is great already, there is no need to extend gameplay with obtuse prompts.

I'm definetly hoping to see either 1.0 or sooner update rolling out and making this awesome, so I can change this to positive. If you think that it's a good bet, the price ain't that high, so it might be safe to believe that this will turn out great..

Absolutely love this game. I have played through both the alpha and beta versions and can't wait for the full release.

Everything in this game is so adorable and lighthearted. The pixel art is beautiful. Overall this game is right up my alley. 

Some reviews complained about the conversations being poorly translated and a bit too "silly", but in my eyes, it's fine the way it is. Sure, it's a little silly, but that fits the overall lighthearted theme of the game.

Recommended, because it's very cute and it will encapsulate you with its magic ✨ 

I invested about 9h so far, so I can't say how well the game does in terms of mid to end game content - it's definitely worth the low price of 13,29€ though! I haven't played any of the Harvest Moon, Story of Seasons or Rune Factory games, which probably served as great influences for Little Witch in the Woods, but I heard a lot about those games and their extensive content. Apparently there are only two people working on Little Witch in the Woods - which seems impressive! - but therefore I doubt that it will ever be able to offer as much content as those life sim giants. This isn't necessarily a bad thing (I for one would be happy to finish a game within a few weeks!) and the developers do deliver quality content.

There are a few wrinkles I'd love to see ironed out over the course of the early access period though, e.g.:
- It's hardly possible to sort or tidy up your inventory (only way to do it is to move items back and forth between your bag and storage).
- The upgrades to the witch's workshop feel very underwhelming. This slow progression just prolongs playtime, without adding more fun.
- The quest overview doesn't show the deadline for the daily deliveries - you need to remember when you accepted a delivery (which I definitely won't if I play this game only once a week).

123990186.review:
I was almost deterred from playing it at the beginning due to the dialogue, but you get used to it and are able to skip through it if you dislike it enough. I personally don't mind how it as i think it helps you know who the characters are and gives you more of a feel of being inside that universe. Once you get off the train and the story starts playing out, the game becomes much more interesting.

This game has a very cozy vibe to it and has similar aspects to Stardew Valley. It has a nice mix of side quests to the main quests to help the Villagers of the town and break up the monotony a little bit. I admit, you have to do a lot of running around to find ingredients for potions, but you get the hang of it after exploring the areas and it's really nothing too different from the running around you do in SDV. Eventually you end up getting a broom, so you can travel a bit faster too. 

I read a previous review that states there was no way to upgrade any of your tools etc., but there are ways, they just take quite a bit of resources. The developers may have fixed that issue since the other review was made though. For upgrades, you can go to Blaine to upgrade your extractor, roaster, cauldron, etc., you go to Kyla to upgrade your storage that's inside your workshop, and you go to Aurea to upgrade your backpack space. It takes quite a bit of grinding, but as long as you do Blaine and Aurea's daily potion quests, it moves along pretty nicely in between the main story activities. 

I'm definitely interested to see how this game progresses. I was bummed to see the fireworks go off and the screen saying "Thank you for playing" lol. Hopefully the developers finish it quickly so we can find out what Kent is really up to and I can see more of those adorable lizards lmao. All in all, great job with the game!

123260438.review:
I've been excited for the development of this game for a long time, and was eager to play it. However, I found it tedious to get into - the long dialogue-heavy intro, the character movement being somewhat slow, then being shown possible game mechanics in the house but not being clear on when/how to use them. Only met 1 villager NPC so far. Tried to come back to it to see the main gameplay loop and get into it, but just haven't gotten enough motivation and interest to do so. 

I think the game's beginning could borrow from what Stardew does well: show 1-2 core mechanics (like farming, or potion-making, or something) for the first in-game day or two. Pace the tutorials for the other mechanics in a way that doesn't feel confusing. Have the character start meeting NPCs early on, to build the player's connection with the game world. Improve the sprite moving speed to be a bit faster. Don't overdo the dialogues that don't build relationships or advance the story. I think the game has a lot of potential and a beautiful visual design, and hope to come back to it in the future once it has been developed more.

123138780.review:
Little Witch in the Woods is a nice and relaxing game. I really liked the "magic" part of it, meaning that you can craft potions and also use them independently of quests, e.g. to gain more materials from creatures or to solve little puzzles. It is also cool, that some of these puzzles are up to you to solve, so there are only hints in the encyclopedia or the surroundings. 
But I have to agree with the other comments, that the gathering of the materials and the crafting of the potions gets repetetive after some time. In the Early Access (EA)-version you also have to craft the same potions or candys almost every day, because the daily quests of the venders do not really change over time (in my case only 3 different types of candy). 
Nevertheless, I think it is already a really good game and it has potential to be even better in the final version, if there is more variety in the daily quests and maybe an option to accelerate the collection of materials: e.g. a garden, where you can grow a limited amount of plants or keep a limited amount of creatures or if someone or something could help you with the gathering.
Besides, I liked the story, because there are quite some mysteries and background stories to be solved. The characters also have their own distinct personalities and the design suits me as well. In the EA version there are also teasers how it will continue and I am looking forward to playing the final version.

122897764.review:
Ok, so there's a lot I like, but unfortunately a lot more I dislike.I am going to be giving the pros and cons of the game and a little bit of my personal suggestions to fix some of the issues. ultimately I intend to give this a thumbs up because I can see this potentially being a very polished and fun game. So let's get into it. 
This game is similar to Stardew Valley in that you talk to townsfolk weather it be business related or just passing by with a greeting. You make potions from the resources you gather around the area to both sell to and solve problems for said villagers. In order to create these potions you have to gather resources from around the area and brew/craft them in the basement of the witches house. This brings me to my first issue. You will see within the first couple in-game days that this become VERY tedious. Some may say "that's just part of the game!" "Monotony is the key to feeling accomplished once you're finished!" 
Not entirely untrue, however there is no "end goal" to this monotony. You don't gather materials to eventually obtain an easier method of doing so. You are forced to walk and gather every single day so you can progress and do it all again next time you need to brew another potion. It get's old pretty fast, especially considering there is absolutely no promise of upgrading this aspect f the game. (I am aware of the broom, it's just another thing to repair every time it breaks.) It would be like if Stardew Valley gave you the sprinklers that you can unlock, but after a number of days you had to go around and refill them with water. There's both an easy and a hard way to solve this. I'll start with the easy.
If the game allowed for some form of fast travel it would cut down GREATLY on the exponentially tedious task of gathering materials every single day. It wouldn't even have to be easy to obtain. Even if it was something that needed to be unlocked it would be better than being forced into it every time. 
My personal suggestion (and more involved/difficult) would be adding some form of growing the specific ingredients you find yourself needing the most. Maybe a sort of greenhouse that can have the available storage upgraded. Or you could only grow basic ingredients that you have found before in the map and you could only grow the more complex one's after it was upgraded. Anything is better than what is currently being showcased.
As for my next major point. The games music is rather charming, don't get me wrong. I enjoy the tracks for most of the areas. Now, I can't say I enjoy them played on repeat for hours on end. Stardew had the right idea with having the music run its course and then stop once it was over for the day. Not to mention there is a very prominent lack of variety in the tracks. this is an easy obvious fix and I don't intend on rambling too much about it due to the game being in early alpha I am certain this will change in some way or another.
The final and most massive problem for the game has to be the dialogue. It's just so h o r r e n d o u s l y awful.
There is a massive plethora of run on awkwardly structured sentences. The main character often is redundant on what she says. A disgusting amount of banter between Ellie and her hat is just completely unnecessary and annoying. Tons of time in this game is spent reading completely ridiculously unrealistic dialogue.The story that could have been told in a one minute cut scene at the beginning of the game is stretched unbelievably long to the point of snapping your attention span like a chickens neck on a dairy farm. It's genuinely like aliens who have never spoke to anyone made this game and are trying to replicate real human speech.    IT    IS    BAD     ... 


Now, with all this being said, yes, I do understand that this game is in VERY early development. and the dialogue and game play is subject to change. I just wanted to point out the things that I at the very least expect to have some attention drawn to them. Because as it stands I cannot recommend this game to any of my friends. The problems are just far too frequent to justify its price right now. I have seen nearly finished games to up for around $15 - $20. And I do not give games a pass on low polish just because they are cute in style. The thing is, there's a lot to do still. And I do hope this game is given more attention before it is officially released. Because I want to enjoy it, but it makes it hard to.

122863506.review:
Little Witch in the Woods is an excellent game under development. I was first sceptical at the beginning but with over 6 hours of game play so far I am satisfied and have vastly enjoyed my time spent on this game. If you are a fan on Stardew Valley, Terraria or Animal Crossing this is the game for you. While, being jam packed with quests and story lines it is quite peaceful and creative to play. For the cost, I am very happy. I definitely this is worth $22.95. It isnt the cheapest game out there but by far not the most expensive.

In my opinion there is plenty to explore and I haven't encountered any bugs or faults with the game which I was impressed by seeing it is still developing as I play. 

Little Witch in the Woods is underrated. I strongly recommend getting this in your next purchase. 

Rated: 8/10.

Edit: Many other reviews mention locked key binds, which personally, I was completely fine with when I got a hold of the controls. However, flexibility to edit key binds or use of controller would be a nice touch and allow for more accessibility and user preference - as the game uses zero mouse the entire way through.

Secondly, there doesn't seem to be a pause option. I believed pressing 'Esc' paused the game but it seems not. If leaving game idol you definitely want to Save the game at the Witches house and Exit to Main Menu if you don't want to lose game play and daily quests as some users stressed that this was a major issue for them. 
If you're a sit down, game for hours straight without leaving your seat, exiting the game when finished player then saving shouldn't be a problem. (Game automatically saves each morning after you sleep)

122288183.review:
Little Witch in the Woods is an adorable little pixel art RPG following Ellie, an apprentice witch, as she explores a magical forest and helps residents of a nearby village. The game begins slow but opens up, inviting you to learn more about the world Ellie resides in. Aside from a few grammatical errors in the dialogue, repetitive story-telling and odd key-bindings, the game is incredibly charming.

As far as I can tell, Little Witch in the Woods plans for a full release in 2023. Currently only offering a prologue and the first chapter with about five hours of playtime. The finished version is planned to have a prologue, three chapters, and an ending. I'm excited to see how this game and its community grows, evolves and expands.

121184613.review:
This is a review after completing all content as of Early Access.

 [u] Bugs and the like. [/u]

[list]
    [*] I got soft locked after opening my quest menu while going up the elevator at the witch's house. I could only use arrow up and arrow down in the quest menu, and I was stuck in place.

    [*] After the aforementioned bug, Virgil says “Just sleep, who cares” when you attempt to clean the inside of the witch’s house when Ellie is supposed to be heading towards the train in the morning after sleeping at the witch's house.

    [*] Kyla asks for 10 piece of rock for the fountain, however in the task list it says stone fragments. 

    [*] The text option says “I’ve asked everyone” instead of “I’ve asked everything” when asking Arden about himself during the [i] Who cursed the Dragon [/i]? quest.

    [*] There is an untranslated section in one of the books that can be bought from Aurea and used to pass time.
[/list]

[u] Tips for people who want to give this game a chance in it's Ealry Acess stages. [/u]
[list]
    [*] Hoard. Everything.
    [*] Storage and tool upgrades will make your life a lot easier.
    [*] Focus less on keeping your broom on max stamina.
[/list]

[u] My favorite things about the game so far. [/u]
[list]
    [*] Rubrum.
    [*] Good pixelart and unique SFX (the lamp cord sound, especially).
    [*] The interaction circle (to turn in quests, for example).
    [*] Passing time using books.
[/list]

[u] Hey Devs, this is what I want to see after Early Access. [/u]
[list]
    [*] MAKE. CONTROLS. REMAPABLE. Including having mouse buttons as an option. People without full keyboards or people who find the controls just plain awkward have a hard time playing this game.
    [*] Please don't include too much grinding. Only the people who enjoy grind-y games will enjoy it if you do.
    [*] Increase broomstick stamina, make stamina drain lower for the broomstick, or add broomstick upgrades PLEASE. It's hard enough grinding for sticks and mud, I don't like part of my house upgrades to be put into keeping the broomstick not on E (no gas).
[/list]

120752796.review:
Little Witch in the Woods has become one of my favorite "cozy games" next to Stardew. The character design & landscape are both incredibly cute and unique. I know this seems like a stretch but the atmosphere and gameplay actually really remind me of the first Pokemon Mystery Dungeon. A cat comes to you in a dream and asks for your help to save the town? Classic Mystery Dungeon. I enjoy the style of gameplay offered where you have 1-2 repetitive daily quests, but at the same time you have to manage your time to progress the story or unlock updates to make your life easier. If you are a fan of cute pixel RPGs this is absolutely the game for you. It is already a 10/10 in my book and I'm very excited for future updates.

Some reviews mention that the dialogue is too simple or too long. I personally disagree, considering most cozy games have a lot of dialogue with getting to know & doing favors for characters being a big part of the game. However, I do think that adding more visuals that display character traits (like what already happens were characters build sandcastles/inspect trees/etc.) would make the characters seem more complex. So I think that was smart for the devs to release that in their next update. Something that I am looking for in a future update would be seasons & seasonal events.

I'm hooked, hope this game does well.

There's plenty of small issues (typos, lack of settings, inconsistencies in interactions with items and game objects, no mouse support and more) [PS: I would love a link to report the bugs and issues I find in this game]

The story seems fun and I can't help but feel it's going to expand alot as I keep playing (Im still relatively early on).
The dialogue strikes a good balance between fun, meta, cute and interest, and most importantly doesn't make me want to skip it all ASAP.
The potion brewing system is great, I hope there's more variety in the future.
The music feels like it lacks work(to be expected of course), some places have no music and there's not much variety.

Now for probably the strongest suit of this game, the artstyle, it's amazing honestly, and what feels like has gotten the most polish out of all the other things in the game. I truly recommend anyone who is a fan of pixel art (and everyone who isn't should also at least look up some screenshots) to play this game, even if it's just for that.

There are alot more pros and cons to this game that I haven't mentioned here of course.

120691856.review:
This game is visually very charming and I love the premise, but it has a lot of flaws. Maybe a lot of these issues will be addressed in the full release, but as of right now it's pretty rough. The number one thing that bothered me about this game is how poorly translated the dialogue is. I know this is a Korean game and you can tell by the way things are translated and the way the characters constantly reference age and speaking formally vs informally. To someone who speaks both Korean and English this will make sense, but to the average English speaking player a lot of the dialogue would be completely nonsensical and annoying to get through. It takes me out of the game a lot to see such repetitive and poorly translated dialogue which detracts from the overall game play. I feel like the quality of this game would skyrocket if they improved this. As of right now the NPCs are also lacking in personality and say basically the same things over and over. I would love it if you could improve your relationships with characters, because the way the game is now there is basically no incentive to talk to any of the NPCs unless you're fulfilling a quest. 

I also found the potion-making (which is pretty much the main point of the game) to be a little repetitive and boring. It would be cool if they made some sort of mini game for the potion making rather than the way it is now. 

On a positive note, I love the visuals, exploration, the creatures, and gathering materials. I think this game has a lot of charm and potential, but I wouldn't recommend purchasing it until they fix some of these issues (especially the poorly translated dialogue. At first I didn't notice it too much but as the game went on I couldn't ignore it. This really needs to be fixed).

120656804.review:
I just want to say, OH my goodness. This game is going to be a GEM once it's out of Early Access, and everything they show now is very promising! Extremely adorable, spirited, and unique.

Pros: What the have now is surprisingly extensive. I expected to run out of things to do quickly, but I just got rid of the vines 5 hours in. The art style is adorable and extremely professionally done, the characters are delightful. 

Cons: The english translation can be pretty choppy at times, and definitely needs the caring hand of an editor to help things be less convoluted and confusing. Its dialogue still has its charm, don't get me wrong! But it definitely is a work in progress.
It holds your hand far too much in places where it doesn't need to, then doesn't explain important things when it needs to (such as, finding the daily 'fetch quest' from the vendors. I ended up selling the item to them at first and was surprised when I failed)

Suggestions for the future: I would love a little bit more sandboxing around your old cottage. Perhaps getting Kyla's help to upgrade and decorate your home, Stardew Valley style. That may allow further variety on what to do when the fetch quests get boring.

120249787.review:
!!!Caution: This Review Contains Spoilers!!! 
*This Review was written based on the early access edition of the game, it may change with further updates*
To Start I'd like to talk about the things I like most. Obviously this game is spilling over with Charm. The protagonist, Ellie, is fun and bubbly and her hat Virgil is a wonderfully down to earth foil. In fact I enjoy the personalities of all the NPC characters and I would love to see them fully fleshed out in the full release.

Something else I'm quite fond of is the crafting and scavenging functions in the game. I enjoy the simple yet satisfying potion brewing experience and the notebook is a nice touch. Resource collection feels fluid and non-tedious and seems well balanced at least for the potions currently included in the early access. 

There isn't enough I can say about the sprites and pixel art in the game, it is top notch in every regard. The fun and bouncy design of the characters, flora, and fauna all add to the relaxing and welcoming charm that this game oozes. I especially enjoy the character dialogue portraits and the notebook renditions of certain models. The soundtrack is lovely as well. The music fits the vibe of the game perfectly. 

Onto some things I think could be improved. I enjoy the interface for the most part but I think the crafting/storage menus could benefit from a free floating cursor and a drag and drop style organizational system. As is it can be difficult to organize storage and items the way you desire.

I have also noticed some performance issues related to entering and exiting areas that require loads. Frame rate drops occur frequently, specifically when the game saves upon leaving the house in the mornings. Some optimization would likely solve this issue. 

I appreciate the attempt to include puzzle aspects to the game but some of the puzzles feel repetitive and boring but this may just come down to a lack of content and therefore limited options. I'd like to see the forest weights puzzle expanded on. It was the best example of progressive puzzle solving in the game. 

For me this is neither here nor there but if you're coming to this game expecting the same level of world exploration as a game like Stardew Valley you will be disappointed. The story here is relatively linear and contained to a small set of locations. I don't mind this seeing as the game is more narrative focused but it isn't your classic farming/crafting game at least not at this point in time. 

The dialogue is also rather clunky at times and some glaring grammatical errors may pull you out of the story. 

I Recommend this game and look forward to future updates :)

119893521.review:
After finishing the early access main quest and most of the side quests and doing some upgrades I have to say I very much enjoyed my time in the woods. The start was a little rough, but it does get better once you start making potions and meeting more characters. This is a fairly slow game in which you collect ingredients and craft potions and candies so you can progress through the story. Quests involve exploring the forest, fetching items and chatting with the locals. You need to collect and process items and then follow the recipes, which you can buy from the traders.

I get that the writing style isn't going to be for everyone, but it fits the main character in my opinion. Some of the exchanges could perhaps be made a little shorter, but on the other hand you're not supposed to be in a hurry.

The gamepad controls could use a bit of work. You need a lot of buttons, both while walking and gathering and while crafting. It's all a bit inconvenient and it slows the game down a bit too much. The menu system for conversations could also be streamlined a bit.

The graphics look nice and cute and have plenty of animations and I like the expressions of the characters in conversations.

The music repeats a lot, but didn't get on my nerves. No complaints.

I played this on Steam Deck and the game worked fine. Not sure why Valve only rates this as "Playable". Some text can be a little too small, but that's my only complaint.

A great start for an early access game. Recommend, even in the current state. I'm looking forward to the next story update.

119860339.review:
I waffled on rating this for awhile... So I loved playing through the demo.  I'll just go pro's/con's

Pro:
- adorable art
- fun NPCs
- cute concepts for how to create potions
- the tools and info recording is fun

Con:
- really grindy for certain items that are always needed; makes it a little difficult to progress when you need to keep going to the starting area to keep building up the starter herbs AND go to the other side of the forest and gather those as there isn't enough time in the day (especially since some gathering has LONG animations or extra actions needed per piece of reagent like the pumpkin puppy fur)
- the currency costs make it so you are in a catch 22 to progress story in a non-boring manner - do the starter area potions for currency or go get the further away herbs to make new things to unlock events; but you need both to progress
- storage is too expensive and goes back to the prior point
- the dialog wasn't too bad in the demo where it's more insinuating that Ellie is overzealous, reckless, but smart.  In the release, they keep basically making it seem like Ellie is an idiot and hates reading despite being the 2nd best witch in her class? It doesn't make sense and it's a bit irritating to keep bringing down the main character like that when it's clear she shouldn't just be an idiot.

I want to be able to recommend but I do think there's a lot that makes it too repetitive and grindy and I'm actually really sad about it.  I enjoyed the demo very much and was glad to see more NPCs and options of things to do.  But the execution isn't great and I'm not a fan of how the dialog is lengthy and devolving the protag into an idiot.

If the dialog and more options for herbs or more storage, I will change the review but right now, I am a bit disappointed.

119772001.review:
This is the first game review I have ever written. Here goes :)

Pros:
- Cuuuute! Love the art.
- Stardew Valley-like game (with an element of visual novel) but you are a little witch that sells potions and saves a village. It is less stressful than Stardew since there is (at this point) no chances of getting killed and the consequence of missing bedtime is only that you sleep in two hours more the next day :)
- I have finished the early access part, but I see that there is a lot of potentiel for new quests, characters and stories to unfold. There was a bit of a mystery cliff-hanger that I am looking forward to see unfold!
- You never get lost in what to do or how to do it. The game guides you well for a relaxing and progressing gameplay.

Important cons:
- The English translations are poor. Note that they are totally understandable but just *weird* sometimes, because there are phrases directly translated in a way that just doesn't work in English (e.g. the phrase "you can speak comfortably", which is always answered with something like "Thank you, then I will speak comfortably" and then they go on to speak the same way as they spoke before and about nothing special in particular.)
- The dialogue is often repetitive and over-the-top cute (e.g. lengthly thank-yous for being such an amazing little witch). In general there seems to be a lot of work still needed for the dialogues to make them more to-the-point and engaging.
- The controls are annoying because you can only move with the arrows and not WASD. I hope this changes.

Less important cons:
- Haven't found any need for all the food I have gotten from villagers yet.
- Storage/backpack is too small. Hope the option for increasing it will be implemented soon because it became annoying at a point.
- It takes too many clicks to end a dialogue with the shopkeepers, which you will do a lot.

Overall I enjoyed it a lot and I hope to see it improve and expand so that I can play it more!

119497271.review:
Review & suggestions: 8-hours in!

First of all.. I fucking love this game. Am I allowed to say that? I FUCKING love this game. I bought it because I love the forest aesthetic and Stardew Valley vibes - but my goodness. The art style, animations, character designs, and pure amount of joy and serotonin I get from this game is incredible. And it's all unique!!! I can guarantee you won't find another game like it anywhere on Steam or elsewhere. This is already one of my favorite games on steam and i'm not even finished yet!!!! I only have two suggestions for the developers and they're really small / self-serving.

1. The controls. When I looked up "little witch in the woods" on google, the very first search result is how to change the key binds. Now I'm 8 hours in to the game so I've gotten a little used to them, but for new players its hard to learn! I would love the option to change keybinds in settings so players can use familiar controls (such as shift to sprint, ctrl to crouch, i/e for inventory, e/enter to interact, etc.) 

2. Affection system. I would *love* to see an affection / friendship system added into the game. All of the characters are amazing and wonderful and I love interacting with them, but I wish there was a reward for being so invested in the characters! (other than Enite's delicious pies!). This is a very selfish suggestion as I really just want Arden to open up to the character more and to get sappy dialogue with Aurea as well as discounted prices if you're nice to the villagers ;)

I absolutely adore this game and can't wait to see more. I'm only at [spoiler] the beginning of building Roy's house and just meeting the White Cat God - [/spoiler] so I know I'm not done with the game yet. But I can't wait to see more (more of the village, expanding the lore of this universe, etc). I am 1000% invested and in love with this game, can't wait to see it blow up.

TLDR; buy this game, you wont regret it.

I understand that this is an early access release and not at all the final product, but I do have some criticisms.

1. There's a lot of dialogue. A LOT. I found myself not very immersed with the story due to how it's written and had to tap Z a bunch of times just to give someone something or when crafting an item. A trim in some areas might do the game some justice.
2. The control scheme was very hard to adjust to. You cannot remap the controls, but I wish that you could.
3. Some of the buttons when interacting with characters has cut off text that you cannot read. (Like when interacting with Diane)
4. I wish that you could pin recipes or that tasks actually tracked how many items you have/need. I caught myself having to check three different windows multiple times just to know what exactly I had to do. If you added a "create job" function for upgrades and whatnot, that would be helpful. Right now the player just has to memorize how many pieces of how many materials they need.

All of that aside, I am really excited for this game. It's like when you read a really good book and you don't know what to do with your life afterwards and there's nothing that seems to compare. That's how I feel after completing what is offered in this preview. I look forward to what the modding community could implement too.

119289040.review:
Review in progress:

Little Witch in the Woods is a beautiful and hilarious RPG that mixes games like Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing with witchcraft. Back in 2021 the first demo came out and even back then I adored the style and story of the game. Since then the developers have added so much more substance to the game and somehow made it even more enjoyable. The art style and animation mixed with the music makes this game magical and adorable. The characters are so enjoyable, hilarious, and fleshed out, and I have absolutely fallen in love with every single one of them. Last but not least the game play is smooth and easy to use and makes gathering materials more enjoyable. There have only been a few issues throughout the game like major grammatical errors/multiple misspelled words in one sentence (mainly at the beginning), characters glitching in and out of existence, text appearing before a scene changes, and music not looping properly leaving the player in silence for at least a minute. These issues don't break the game in anyway, the worst that could happen is not being able to understand some dialogue. So all in all this game is amazing, adorable, hilarious, and a good time, and I would recommend it to everyone, issues and all.

119286404.review:
~ BE AWARE ~
this game is early access - it's not a complete game.
i played 15 hrs of this darling little game before reaching the "end" and i'll definitely be playing more. i loved crafting potions and discovering the different animals, plants, and potions. it's a chill & cozy little game, with zero combat (unless you count chasing down a pumpkin terrier.. those were infuriating lol). 

my only complaint are the keybinds the dev chose. you cannot rebind them to other buttons, and you're forced to use the arrow keys to move, z to interact, s for inventory, x for cancel.... it's just terrible. i got accustomed to it, but i disliked it the entire time. allowing for rebinding is a must.

overall, i'd highly recommend this cute little magical crafting game. the conversations are funny and charming, the potions are simple yet each are different, gathering items is unique with each item, and the music is perfect for cultivating the coziest little craft/farm game.  i can't wait for the full game release & hope it gets the love that it deserves.

119169078.review:
I want to love this game. The graphics are great, the soundtrack is great, the overall design and intrigue is also great. The dialogue... is not-so-great. I don't want to be harsh on this game because it's early access, but in it's current state I can't play this game without becoming increasingly frustrated at the amount of pointless dialogue. If the "hat" character was entirely muted, nothing of importance would be detracted. 

- Every time anything interesting happens, the hat talks.
- Every time you discover an item/mechanic/location and wonder "What is this?", don't worry, because the hat will tell you all about it.
- Did the hat tell you about something once? Did you miss it? Don't worry the hat will tell you 3 more times.
- Are you talking to another NPC? The hat will also chime in.

The game is less of a "game" and more of a repetitive visual novel at this point.

TL;DR - Do you want a Navi "Hey Listen" simulator, but only far more garrulous? You've come to the right place.

I will change this review the same day if/when this is patched.

119104736.review:
I found Little Witch in the Woods to be an incredibly charming and adorable early-access game. I am really looking forward to seeing how this game progresses and it’s admirable that the developers want to have players be involved with the final result.

Pros:

This game is adorable. I couldn’t stop smiling every time I encountered a new character, part of the map, and creatures. (My personal favorite was the Blue Bubble Lizard, absolutely adorable).

This is a comfort game, for sure. If you enjoy games like Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing to wind down, this will likely have a similar effect on you. I loved foraging and the whole workshop concept. I felt like I could spend hours just crafting potions and other items.

I didn’t find any part of the game to be particularly difficult to the point of getting stuck, it was rather smooth sailing which I also believe could be ideal for people that are looking for a relaxing game that won’t get frustrating.

Cons:

The controls are a bit awkward, it took me a while to adjust to this. Not a complete deal breaker, but might be worth adjusting for the final game.

Other notes:

I would love to see mushroom foraging in the future. Maybe this is in the works because there’s details about certain mushrooms in a book you can read. Being able to forage, extract/roast, and make potions out of mushrooms would just add that much more.

Season changes in this game could be REALLY cool, and potentially moon phases too.

Overall I really enjoyed this game and it’s by far one of my favorites now! Very well done <3

Honestly if someone is like me and still wants to play it; I'd say go for it, cause it's a lovely game to relax with.

119056687.review:
[Game play] 
I normally have a hard time playing games similar to this for long periods of time, but I was glued to the cute art style and chill game play. Though the game play has a lot of repetitiveness to doing tasks, it has a fulfilling reward for your work as you progress through the game. The puzzles I would say are on the easier side, which is fine, but I'd still like a bit of a harder challenge in thinking about what potions I need to apply to progress through the puzzle. I will say even though I enjoy the repetitive game play I know some may not so do be aware of this if you're thinking about buying it.
[More in depth thoughts]
The characters have good dialog, though not a lot of it if you try to have a longer conversation with them similar to Stardew Valley's conversations, but still with more variation. The music is does its job pretty well, though some of the songs feel a little lacking in composition due to the use of one or two instruments being used at a time for long portions or the song. (though they are looped so it could just be I've listened to it to long) But just because it's simple doesn't mean its bad, I just think more could possibly be added to add variety in the melody. As I said earlier the art style is very cute (which is actually how this game caught my eye) and I really enjoy it! the characters are all really unique in design and the outfit design is very good. I'm pretty passionate when it comes to art ,so things that others may not think about in the art I really appreciate. (I also noticed the Ellie waddles like the bullets in Enter the Gungeon, don't know if that was intentional or not, but I still appreciate it.
[Ideas for improvement]
- there are a frequent errors in the text boxes that need to get fixed
- Character models disappearing mostly Rubrum when he leaves town to build his castle
- add more main game play mechanics for the player to have fun with
[Ideas being: cooking, decorating,fishing, maybe even some sort of broom flying minigame? (farming, though I don't really see this happening)
-more unique quests from the towns folk

I know developing a game is hard and it's easy for a player to be nit picking & biased, but I understand that this game is still in early development. So I hope that if any devs read this whole thing (essay) that this will be good feedback for them to better develop this game.

My final rating: 65/100 

Final comments:Your game has great potential, though its short right now I believe you'll be able to add more content to boost the length of the game while adding more variety in game, and that being said I wish you guys luck on developing the game and I can't wait to see this game become more developed!

118923061.review:
This will be an ongoing review for obvious reasons but I want to post it regardless because this game has an absolute TON of potential and is already an awesome experience.

Right, here goes:

Pros -

Excellent art style
Fun gameplay loop
Likeable characters who are both amusing and down-to-earth
Mechanics that are simple enough to follow but also not so simple that it ends up being boring
Nice controls
Characterful sprites and designs with a lot of charm in even the most innocuous of things like reagents
Large game world with plenty to see and do

Cons (sort of) -

Performance is definitely a mixed bag but it's still fun but the stutter can cause headaches. This is seemingly a known issue which the developer is working to fix
The theme is not entirely cheery and can be a bit sad but... yeah, this is subjective to say the very least and I don't mind that one bit

Overall thoughts: This game is charming, well put together and still evolving and is already one of my favourite games in this pixel-art style along with Stardew Valley, Sun Haven and many others. If you like the look of this game and it's theme, go for it! Remember it's an Early Access game and there is still a lot to be added and ironed out and you will likely enjoy this game for the charming little world the developer has created. Very very nice game!

118918224.review:
I loved playing this early access! It's cute and relaxing; I loved the townspeople and a lot of the ideas for the crafting mechanics and upgrades, and I'm very interested to see where the underlying story goes from here. 
I don't normally leave reviews but I decided to leave some constructive feedback/ ideas for changes since the full game is still in progress:
1. the foraging system can get pretty old very fast, since everything is in the same location and resets every day. It would be better to have this more randomized but for certain items have a way to grow them yourself. Plus, some ingredients are needed in larger quantity for extraction but are much more limited in how you are able to obtain them, the feathers especially. 
2. you may want to explicitly say when the character "pass-out" function is. It ended up being a terrifying trial and error for some time, lol. 
3. the storage system was a little confusing to me, as I had two chests but only one of which i could actually use for the most part, and the expensive upgrades to the one were only for one line of slots, not another page. 
4. I would appreciate it if we could pull up the recipe book in the potions crafting menu
5. Please let me pay back that witch lady. Please it weighs on my conscious lmao
6. I think it would be nice to add in little events with the townsfolk, like cooking with enite and arden, or making tea with rubrum, etc. A gifting system might also be nice. 
7. I would appreciate a little customization in terms of our house and the area around it!
8. We were supposed to be able to interact with one character repeatedly if we crafted a certain potion and consumed it before sleeping, but it never worked more than that one time- probably something put into the full game but just wanted to point it out here

Besides (1) those are really just some nitpicks and I really enjoyed this game overall!!

-The experience while exploring is so smooth. I love seeing the cute mobs running around!
-The journal is really detailed and complete, super helpful!
-You can figure out things yourself without the game telling you, and that's great.
-You'll make some decisions that will actually be reflected in the game. 
Small ones, but they still count! ♥
-There's always something to do; From gathering or making your potions, to side quests.
-The days are not too long, nor too short, and you can save anytime!

... Well, I think we could say I love everything about it, haha. 

[b] There's also a couple of things I'd "change": [/b]

-I think the font would look nice if it had that "pixel" style, too (mostly talking about the clock and the UI), but everything is super well placed and it still looks good, this is just a personal opinion.  
-I've also seen a couple of typos in the dialogues (nothing too bad), but since the game is in early access and it's getting updated constantly, I think they'll get fixed soon!

[b] I can't wait to see the game finished, and I really hope they add achievements and badges, that'd be amazing. Also translations to other languages, so more people could enjoy it!! I highly recommend it, they've done a fantastic job. ♥ [/b]

118554543.review:
Hands down, this is one of the best games I've ever played. As someone who loves Stardew Valley, Animal Crossing, and Story of Seasons, Little Witch in the Woods scratches that casual rpg, craft and collect, puzzle-solving itch in adorable pixel graphics and in-depth world building. It's a little rough around the edges, but the developers have sound core concepts for an early access game. My Pros and Cons list (spoilers ahead!):

[b]Pros[/b]

- Rich ecosystems featuring animals and plants with unique behaviors and collection methods
- Intricate world-building
- Choose your own pacing
- Relatively engaging quest lines
- A fun and quirky cast of characters
- Adorable graphics
- Tests your puzzle-solving skills
- The BROOM

[b]Cons[/b]

- Controls on keyboard are slightly clunky, especially with the broom. Space and shift are way too far from each other. I really hope the devs let the player map their own keys in the future!
- Minor glitching. At least when it comes to the little fox, because he randomly appears and disappears sometime.
- Dialogue. This is a major pet peeve of mine as a creative writer with a special focus on dialogue. This is especially prevalent in the intro cutscene, where the conversation jumps back and forth between topics (namely talking about the MC's boredom and info that advances the plot), while introducing information about the world that seems ham-fisted. I really hope the devs fix this in the full release, since dialogue plays a heavy role in characterization and the game places heavy emphasis on relationship building with the NPCs. 
- Wading through tons of dialogue every time to reach the special orders section from Diane. This is especially frustrating when I try to submit the requested potions and there's a new special order that day, because the dialogue I have to go through (even with holding down ctrl) is even longer. It becomes tedious. I hope further down the line, there's just an order board where all the available orders—what you have to submit and when is the deadline—is incorporated into the game. Something similar to the task board outside of Pierre's Store in Stardew Valley. 
- Collecting ingredients becomes tedious after 9 hours of playing. The methods to collect them are fantastic enough as is, so there's no need to improve on that front. However, having to travel to their unique locations to collect them becomes old after a while. Maybe there could be a limited farming feature in the future? Kind of like how players have a mini garden in the Sereniteapot for Genshin Impact. It doesn't grant high yields of materials due to the small number of plots, but it gives the players some breathing room when it comes to collecting materials they commonly need or can become annoying to obtain in the long run. 
- Constant back and forth to check ingredient stores and required materials necessary to craft something. I find that this is a major issue ALL games in the farming/collecting/crafting genre suffer from. I'd love to see a system where you can tag recipes you've already learned (whether it's a potion, or an upgrade for your cauldron/storage/etc) and have an overlay in the corner that keeps track of how many of that particular material you have in your backpack, or backpack AND storage. Kind of like in classic MMORPGs where they have a ticker in the corner that keeps track of your quests. Maybe this could be an upgrade you work for in game?

[b]Musings for Possible Future Features[/b]
- Right now, it doesn't seem like the shop feature has been implemented for Roy. I mentioned earlier how collecting ingredients can be tedious after a while, so I'm hoping Roy will be selling ingredients harvested from plants. Maybe he can sell seeds for the limited garden idea?
- A map would be great. This might just be me, but I still get a little turned around by the game's map despite having 14 hours in the game at this point. This would be especially helpful if it can show the locations of all the different materials you can get in game. Maybe unlocking parts of the map can occur when you first interact with the signpost in the area? And the markers for where you can obtain materials can appear as a toggled option once you collected a certain amount?
- Broom upgrades. I would love to see this. I adore using the broom, but I find it drifts too much and it runs out of durability way too quickly. So I'm hoping there will be a way for the player to improve their broom in-game. 
- Other biomes and locations! I'm honestly excited to see what the devs come up with. The forest-mountain-waterfall biome for the early access are fantastic enough. So what can the devs come up with for a winter wonderland? A beach? Crystal caverns? A cloud city? A volcano? A haunted castle? (I'm honestly curious how they would incorporate a haunted castle, something classically horror and man-made, in a game with an emphasis on cutesy graphics and the wonders of nature)
- Future upgrades for the devices in the potions lab to craft/process multiple different potions/materials at once. Right now, the upgrades increase the quantity of the same material that can be processed at once, so I'd love to see future upgrades that allow you to process different materials at once. 

To recap, this is one of the best games I've ever played and can't WAIT to see the full release for. I love the unique behavior of the flora and fauna and the way they make the world more magical—pun intended. The characters are varied and easily likeable. The pixel graphics are fantastic. You decide the pacing, and there's enough quests and tasks in the main and minor story lines—not to mention the mystery element to the plot!—to keep the player engaged for a LONG time. There's just the issue regarding dialogue and something to keep track of materials to hammer out, but overall, this game has a ton of potential and I am seriously glad I came across this!!!

Controls feel clunky, more because of the in game movement rather than the buttons.

118473384.review:
**PLEASE NOTE: THIS GAME IS IN EARLY ACCESS.**
I purchased the game in its current state after seeing a YouTube video of a content creator playing it, and I was not disappointed at all. Is this game perfect? Not at all, but that's part of what the "early access" tag means, and players should respect that as such. With that being said, here's what I see:

Pros:
- Extremely cute and well drawn pixel avatars of characters
- Beautiful artwork with landscape and interactive elements
- Likable characters with cute and interesting backstory
- A relaxing feel where you are not pushed to complete the main quests within a certain time frame
- PLENTY of side quests for those of you who enjoy doing random extras (like me)
- Creative recipe and potion/candy cooking setup dependent on specific ingredients and settings to make correctly

The list of pros I could definitely continue with for a bit, because they strongly outweigh the cons. However, as a recommendation, here are some things that the game could stand to improve on:

Cons:
- Script - very drawn out, does not feel like natural English conversation (As a note to the developers, consider working with a script writer to determine what is necessary and what is not. That will help clean up the script to be more engaging to players.)
- Occasional lag in button reaction time
- Occasional interaction problems where element being interacted with will show a lack of button press (the gauge will go down instead of up when trying to do something like shaking a tree for branches)
- Button mapping - Although I myself adjusted to the selected controls, it might not hurt to allow customizable button mapping for other players who prefer the WASD format.

I sincerely cannot wait for the next phase of development on this game. I truly do believe it's the kind of game I've been waiting for for some time, because I'm hooked in on the early access build! Keep up the great work, developers!

If I could give this a rating, I'd give it a solid 3.5/5 stars.

It is SO CUTE! Wow, incredibly adorable. However it's clear that the appearance of the game is where the entirety of the budget and time went to. If you are going to have an exclusively story driven game it needs to be a good story. So far it has been a LOT of dialogue and not very engaging. 118139898.review:
Little Witch in the Woods was my first ever early-access game. It is super cute, soothing and healing. I absolutely adore the pixel art, every animation looks stunning and i loved the mechanic of potion making. I've seen few people pointing out wrong English spelling but i haven't encountered it. Everything was as it should be. 

The only issue that i've had was Rubrum suddenly being invisible. You could talk to him and he would appear soon but he just wasn't there. It happened only three times and haven't done anything to gameplay so i won't treat it as a big flaw. 
Otherwise the game was super fun to play. I really like the dialogues and characters - they all have their charms. I think my favorite one besides Ellie might be Kent. His suspicious and mysterious character plays a really big role in the story-telling, at least for me. 
The early-access story already finished and i can't wait for the full release. I already want to go back into this chill, magical story and meet other villagers of Wisteria. There's also so many secrets for us to discover.

Gathering ingredients and recording them in a journal is really well-made. Ellie drawings are super cute and the journal really helps while making potions. I really enjoyed Mandrake's sound effects while picking up. 
The whole process of collecting isn't boring at all and using broom to move to places faster is really useful. 
I also really like the map. For early-access it's really big i think and i hope we'll get to see even more beautiful places in the future. 
A big plus for the beautiful background music ! It's really chill and enjoyable <3

I'd recommend this game  to literally everyone. I myself am not a big fan of so-called "slow" and chill games but Little Witch really changed my point of view. It's really an awesome game with good plot, characters and art so be sure to grab it and play it as fast as possible !!!

118127648.review:
This game is great. The cool art and the relaxed theme do bring out the game very well. Each of the characters are unique, and have quite a bit of character. Overall this is an extremely polished game, with minimal bugs and a very smooth gameplay experience.

However, much of the gameplay revolves on collecting and gathering resources for a potion or medicine. This takes some time, and can be frustrating, especially if you need to go all the way back up the mountain to collect a resource, or having to wait to night to wait for a resource you neglected to become available.

The whole game is about 7-8 hours, and has much promise, with some hints of features that can be fleshed out in the future.

118086871.review:
I loved this game, and am very excited for when they add more to it. It's more story driven than other games I've played where crafting and gathering are the primary actions you take outside of your interactions with npcs. The writing of the characters is charmingly youthful, and reminds me of playing tabletop rpgs with friends somehow. The localization of the story is pretty good, despite being a little literally translated during jokes about formal speech and a could of idioms. It would be exciting to see another pass at the english localization to perfect those moments, but they certainly don't break me out of having a nice time with these sweet characters.

The art style is cute as heck. I adore the magical critters in the forest, and that we aren't fighting them to gather magical ingredients. And I was pleasantly surprised that so few of the speaking characters are human. I think the only character design that I'm not in love with is Arden the dragon, he looks more like an alligator than a dragon. However, dragon is a big enough category that I honestly think that's fine even if it's not my favorite.

As far as how buggy vs polished it was for me: it is by far the most polished early access game I've played. I think the only bug I ran into was the little fox sometimes turning invisible during a couple of animations, but I wasn't able to reproduce it consistently. I honestly forgot I was playing a game that isn't technically  finished, right up until I reached it's celebratory end point.

alright, normally i'm not much of a serious reviewer as I feel it wastes my time.
But I will make an exception for this game because i'd been following the development for 2 years and now that I own it, I have some stuff to say.

Disclaimer: The game is still, clearly, in early acces and neither have I done everything the game has to offer in the 8 hours i've played it. If I remember I will update this review when the game has major updates or is out fully.

To cut it short, very fun and wholesome game and I DO recommend it! If you enjoy a simple slice of life experience and want to support development for a small indie game, do it! Go buy the game.

However, the game is very much not finished, like clearly.

I have caught the games a few times missing the english translation, though this isn't too bothersome. 
The thing that bothers me the most is the unchangable keybinds, you HAVE to play on arrow keys and as someone with carpal tunnel, I change controls quite a bit in video games because playing with the same set of controls for hours really hurts my hands. But I am willing to keep up with it because I assume this will be changed with updates.

The thing I am most excited for is fleshed out characterisation. For now most of the characters feel, robotic? As in their dialogue feels unfinished and not natural or flavorfull. This (for now) doesn't help with figuring out quests, because you have to talk to the npc's to figure out what your next quest is, yet their dialogue feels so unreal that I can't always figure out what they (or more so the game) wants me to do. 

But even with all that robotic dialogue, I WANT TO talk to the npc's, the game is great at making me want to do things. I want to buy stuff, I want to explore and I want to figure out new potion and crafting recipes. So even with all the short comings the game has for now, I'd still recommend it for the wholesome and fun experience you can have with it.

I enjoyed playing the first chapter of Little Witch in the Woods. I will note that I used a Steam controller, as the game controls were easier to navigate that way (rather than using the keyboard). Overall, I liked the main character Ellie & her quests. The world seems rich with interesting plants & creatures. 

The game does feel a bit clunky when navigating the dialogue menus, especially for the 'shops'. And particularly with Diane, it is slow-going having to back out through every sub-menu until finally being able to say "Good Bye."  Having a Good Bye or immediate Exit button on each dialogue menu would be helpful. 

Other controls took a few minutes to figure out (such as throwing or drinking potions), I think because the cues on screen may blend in with the background too much... I also have a somewhat large monitor and didn't realize at first that additional information was sometimes appearing at the bottom of the screen. 

I am looking forward to learning more about Ellie, the forest, and the village. I know this is the first chapter, so here are things I am hoping to see/do in the full game:
1) visit the flower shop and interact with Roy there
2) learn more about Arden's past 
3) maybe go foraging with Roy and/or Rubrum for tea ingredients... and make tea! 
4) definitely looking forward to opening up more of the map, and adding more plant & creature information to Ellie's journal
5) Hopefully have more Witch reference books to add to the Witch House library. I was a bit sad that the mushroom book was only a few pages long. 
6) I hope we get to meet more characters from other, nearby villages. 

I am excited to play the full version of this game when it is released.

117624283.review:
I'm on the fence, I'm going no because it is not a 92% recent / 91% overall quality game.  If it was 65-70% I'd go yes, 75% maybe... 80% and up I'd be saying nah.

Still gunna play it

Graphics are what they are, you will notice some hitching if you move quickly, its minor which actually makes it worse on the eyes

Gameplay is pretty basic, go collect things, use things to make potions, use potions to clear new area, repeat.

The issue is that its essentially going to be a grind fest game, go grind up a bunch of stuff, use that bunch of stuff up to grind up a bunch of other stuff, use that stuff up to grind a third group of things.  Then use that third group to do something minor.  Now go back to grinding up the bunch of stuff square one because reasons...

Essentially you are making a bunch of single use stuff that gets you a handful of other stuff, which you do a few times to get another single use thing, which gets you a handful of other stuff, which gives you a single use thing that you use then have to start again... its already scaling up and its going to be painful.

Controls are pretty abysmal, wasd isn't a thing, you can use the arrow keys.  Which means you'll be going to the controller, which is passible but still poor.  Coupled with the above single use items that take a tick to farm up then they get wiffed on use and you have to go redo it is poor design.

TLDR:

Graphics - mediocre
Performance - sub-mediocre
Gameplay - medicore
Controls - poor
Tedium - increasing

117599020.review:
After about 11 hours of playing this game I feel like I can confidently say that it is becoming one of my favorites.

Soundtrack and sound effects are great. I love the nice, relaxing background music and I actually caught myself not needing to play my own music in the background while playing, which is rare.
I love the art style, it reminds me of Stardew a lot, and Stardew is one of my top 5 games, so it is definitely a positive. The character design has been great so far, every new character is a pleasure to look at.
The dialogues could definitely use some improvements. There are a few grammatical/spelling errors here and there, and some sentences are a bit confusing and do not sound natural, but it does not take away from the playing experience.
I am enjoying the lore, the story, and the game mechanics. An options for skipping dialogues could be useful. Also, some sort of relationship building  with other characters through dialogue and different friendship levels could be fun!
The only negative thing that is a bit annoying are the controls. The key binds are really random and do not make sense, and there is no option to rebind them, at least I did not find one. Even after 11 hours I am still not used the controls. 
Overall it is a very chill, relaxing game. There is a lot of repetitiveness, which is normal for these kind of games, so if you are not into it, you will probably get bored. There is a lot of room for improvements, but I am really enjoying it so far.

117590607.review:
Consider this a review specifically of the Early Access version of Little Witch. I'll happily revisit the game and update my review after EA, and I look forward to seeing how it improves.

~~~~
Pros:
~~~~
*Little Witch is rated A for adorable. The pixel art, animations, character design, conversation portraits, names of plants and animals, activities like chasing pumpkin pups or blossom birds, even just the basic concepts of many things in game, like the fact that you brew magical candy. It's all so cute.

*A cozy cottagecore vibe is the game's other main strength. It doesn't want you stressing about crop schedules and remembering when someone's birthday is or which villager likes to eat amethyst, it just wants you to relax, and it is pretty good at fostering that relaxation as long as it doesn't get in its own way with clunky controls and unwanted dialogue interruptions.

*No combat! At least none that I've encountered yet. That's more of a sub-point to the last one, but worth mentioning on its own. In a world innundated with games about fighting, it's nice just to be nice for a while. If there is some kind of combat later in the game please correct me in the comments.

*I liked that a couple of quest-related mandatory long walks across the map were skipped with cutscenes. The world is pretty cute and worth exploring, but less tedium is appreciated now and then.

*Lastly, and it's a small thing, but an unexpected VA11-HALL-A reference at the start made me giggle.

~~~~
Cons:
~~~~
*Sometimes the game isn't cute and it's jarring. Newer Disney and Pixar movies blend some adult humour into kid friendly films really well, and Sunny Side Up should take notes. Ellie's sense of humour tends more toward crass or juvenile than subtly mature.

*Little Witch leans heavily into a retro game vibe, and sadly there are areas where that detracts from the game. The controls are spot-on old school, and distractingly bad for it. Arrow keys to move, Z to select/activate/do everything, Q-W or E-R to scroll through things, S to open one menu and D for another (with no button to smoothly swap between them without backing out), X to cancel. Inventory management is awful just because of the controls involved, and potion brewing, one of the game's main activities, is similarly badly handled. It's a constant annoyance to contort my hand to get anything done and a session any longer than my two hours as of writing this review will definitely leave my hand cramped if I don't switch over to playing on my Azeron soon.

*The worse sin however is Little Witch's bad writing. Dialogue is sometimes stilted, frequently repetitive or abrupt, and overall amateurish. Many characters immediately declare their motivations and history, and when they don't there's a clearly labeled button to prompt them to do so. Inexplicably there is also a button dedicated to prompting NPCs to spout the kind of meaningless jibber jabber you automatically tune out or skip whenever possible in games where very litte effort was put into the dialogue (and  it pains me to write that as a person who enjoys the roleplaying aspect of games and often hears out everything NPCs have to say—I'm not usually a dialogue skipper). Virgil, Ellie's talking hat companion, is a modern day Navi, ever ready to interrupt you in the middle of something with a reminder that you haven't mashed the "skip dialogue" button in a while. All of this is pretty unforgivable for a game that bills itself as being all about the story.

So, if the gameplay is intentionally spare to focus on the story, and the story makes you want to skip everything, you have to ask yourself what's left? Well gosh, it's just lucky that it's so darn cute.

I love how it starts out and the progression towards more complex potions and log entries definitely keeps me engrossed. I ended up spending 17 hours playing what they have to offer (total game play is slotted around 5 hrs) because I kept getting lost in the daily witch grind! The recipes and ingredients involved are creative and all have their own unique traits. The animations and character models are super cute and cared for, although I am a little sad there's no character voices. I also really loved how randomized the sprites are in Wisteria, they really feel like they have places to be and things to do! The only complaints I have are that the character text is often a bit garbled, my sprite for Rubrum would often blink in and out of existence and that the cues for when to use a potion to your benefit (ex: throwing nutrition potion on pumpkin terrier to expose him and get more fur, or drinking twinkle potions to make yourself illuminate) aren't as clear as I think they could be since I only could figure those two examples out from a walk-through. All in all, super cute and rewarding crafting game and I cant wait for future updates!

117328856.review:
Pros:
Very enjoyable little game and I can't wait for more content. Whilst there is a certain amount of resource farming, I would say  it's not too onerous - more on the "today I am collecting X and Y" kind of plan - most plans and upgrades can be achieved in a few days most. I did the shop quests every day and I found time to do everything else and also if I was missing something it was easy enough to scrounge up almost always within the same day. 

I've not noticed anything have a time limit (and I've played through the whole thing in about twice the time The Internet says it should take), so I haven't noticed any deadline goals, such as in Stardew. 

It has a built in "don't hoard excessive amounts" factor built in - which I really like, as a video game resource hoarder. It made me actually PLAY the game and gather as I go along and have fun doing it as well as have a focus. Instead of going "well once I have everything I can conceivably need then I will Have Fun..." and then essentially spamming out all the story in 10 minutes. This works really well with the achieveability of the goals you want so you don't HAVE to harvest the same resource every day for a long term stockpiling project (eg Hardwood in Stardew where once you've cleared the farm you really DO need to visit the secret forest every day if you have a project planned). 

The music is lovely and relaxing too. The art is adorable. 

Cons:
My one big criticism is the conversation trees. There's a lot of buttons to go through for most interactions - doing the daily shop quests I found myself just mindlessly mashing Z a lot. 

The opening dialogue is also very long and clunky - again I ended up mashing Z far more than I should.

For the love of anything please let me sort my inventory

Obviously it is early access but I would quite like some achievements scattered in to the mix for additional side projects to do. 

TLDR: a fun and soothing game, highly recommended

I did not realize it was in early access because all I saw was a cute witch game and hopped right on. Then I saw "Thank you for playing The Little Witch In The Woods" and realized this game was early access. I realized how much I loved this game when I was so disappointed I had to wait for more. Early access is good for feedback though, so here's what feedback I would give:
I love the writing. It's super cute! Sometimes I feel like the characters do talk about things they should know about themselves that they don't need to repeat that could be implied instead of said. That would improve the quality of writing in this game and make it come across more cohesive. 
I also love the world building. The pen and paper to hit new discoveries is definitely amazing! I would be excited to see more hidden areas in the game, as well as a larger map. A big part of the excitement of this game so far has been the question "What will I discover next?" I would be so excited if more of those moments were added. I also notice that when it comes to identifying specific items with the quill, it doesn't work because you're climbing on branches. Also as far as glitches go, Rubrum randomly disappears sometimes which can break immersion in the game. It's pretty often this happens. 
I love the system for making potions and candies. The only thing I hope is to see more creatures to discover, and more potions to be made!
Also I think it would be awesome if you could develop relationships with villagers further than their standard dialog. 
Overall this is an amazing game and I will be so excited when I can play more!

116885101.review:
[b]DISCLAIMERS[/b]
- I play on a custom keyboard.
- Nothing about this game says it tries to be, or should ever be, a Stardew-esque game aside from the use of pixel art and the time/resource management required.
- I will add to, and edit, this review as time goes on if I feel something needs to be mentioned

Short Review:
[b]PROS[/b]
- Relaxed, calming atmosphere
- Go at your pace
- Fluid animations
- Clear sound indicators
- Cute art style
- Clear direction with quests, with room to explore

[b]CONS[/b]
- No control remapping (The devs are aware of this desire among the players and are looking into a way to implement the feature)
- Relatively short (REMINDER: Early Access)
- Occasional bugs (Early Access, the devs do work hard to remedy these as they are revealed)

[b][u]***FULL REVIEW BELOW***[/u][/b]

Little Witch in the Woods is a wonderfully relaxing and warmhearted time and resource management game, with some puzzle elements. The game has no overall time limit, however there are two portions of the game that are time-restricted. The game presents a very light, cute art style, and a very calm atmosphere. The interactions within the game seem to be intended to not rush the player, you go at whatever pace you feel the need to.

The game is in early access, and as such is a rather short game. The near 9 hours I have on record at time of writing this review was by no means the quickest time to complete the game.

The game is designed in such a way that progression is linear, but rate of progression is not intended to be constant. You chose how long it takes you to progress. If you want to spend the day doing everything you can to progress faster you may. Otherwise if you wish to spend a few days just gathering ingredients for potions and storing them, that's also an option.

It is in no way meant to impart stress, or any feeling of urgency, while you enjoy the atmosphere.

[b]Technical/Mechanics:[/b]
To say the game is not optimized for keyboard, in my opinion, would be wrong. It is designed around the QWERTY layout as that is still the most common layout globally. There is no current way to remap controls. If you play on something other than QWERTY then you may run into some hardships with the game. I did not play this with a gamepad so I have no input on that. In my case my BACKSPACE is on the bottom of my keyboard near my left thumb, this meant it was difficult to easily move faster, the sprint button is SPACE, however sprinting is hardly necessary in the game.

[b]There is no mouse support for the game. There is no need for mouse support in the game. Controls are either KB or Gamepad[/b]

The rest of this section will be marked as a spoiler in case people would rather figure these mechanics out for themselves

[spoiler]Each day of the game starts at 8AM. This is the first time restriction in the game. So long as you sleep between 8PM and 12AM the next day will start at 8AM. If you are not in bed by 12AM the game forces you to sleep and start a new day, in this case the day starts at 10AM, costing you 2 minutes of potential play.

Game time progresses at 1 hour per minute spent playing and progresses in 10 minute intervals.
Time does not update until the 10 seconds have passed for the 10 minutes. So you have 9 seconds between each interval before updating to the next.
As a playable day is 8AM-1150PM you have 13 minutes and 59 seconds given to each day.

The second time-restricted portion of the game is the daily quests. You have from 8AM (at the earliest, but whenever you choose to start the quest is your start time) until 6PM the following day to complete these. In total giving you 23 minutes and 59 seconds to complete the two daily quests. These quests can be completed within the day you receive them assuming you start them first.

Your personal inventory, and your at home storage, are fairly limited at the start. Your personal inventory, after about 6 quests with the first daily quest NPC you meet, can be upgraded by that NPC. Your storage upgrades come later.

The game does have a stamina gauge. When the stamina is out you are not able to gather or sprint, however you suffer no other consequences. Eating food allows you to regain a portion of your stamina, which would allow you then to gather more or sprint home.

The second daily quest NPC is what allows you to upgrade your workshop. These upgrades will allow you to process multiple of each ingredient as well as craft more potions at a time. That NPCs daily quests give you the currency needed to perform those upgrades.

Certain creatures that are hidden or hard to see will have sound cues when you're nearby.
[/spoiler]
