116793619.review:
At time of writing, I have played through what I believe are all of the main story quests, and a handful of side quests for the villagers. I went through things fairly quickly, so I would suspect for most folks this is an 8-12 hour game right now. There are plenty of mysteries and little seeds of things yet-to-be-discovered, so I'm looking forward to seeing those fill out. 

Because there are a lot of simulator comparisons, I want to point this out: the game is quite linear. There's a main quest line that takes you through the story and builds out a lot of the lore of this world, some side quests available for specific characters to give them more dialogue and interaction, and a few repeatable quests so you can get the in-game currencies.

As long as you're expecting a linear game, I think it's great. I enjoy the really painterly pixel art, the dialogue between the characters, and the world that the developers have built-- beyond what you see, there is a much bigger world described through dialogue, and it's just fascinating. 

If that all sounds great, I would recommend it! Also, if you have played other crafting games and don't like not knowing what to do next, this game is absolutely for you-- ALMOST always, it's fairly clear what your next steps are and how to get there. 

Also: I played this game using either a Steam Deck or a controller, and both worked great for me. From what I've heard about the keyboard experience, I would definitely recommend a controller.

116655423.review:
Quite similar in style to Stardew Valley. There's no combat though, it's overall relaxing and more focused on gathering and storyline. 

It's obvious that it's not finished yet as the storyline cuts off abruptly, but I didn't mind as getting to that point took me 16 hours of gameplay. There are some errors in the text, but nothing too bad. The controls were the most bothersome and I hope the developers are going to change this for the final release - there are a ton of different buttons to memorise for stuff like scrolling through various menu options and I kept messing it up, very counterintuitive. If it allowed for using a mouse, the controls could be much easier. Sometimes clicking through repeating lines of dialogue until I can get to the part where I deliver the quest item was tedious too, so I'd have preferred having a shorter way to navigate the NPC talk menus when I'm just buying or selling. Oh, and I basically never used the broom, maybe I'm just not adept at the controls but I didn't find it much faster since I kept bumping into stuff. The character has a nice walking speed so I didn't mind much.

If you hate Stardew Valley and aren't up for repeated farming of ingredients, this game might not be for you. I enjoyed the gathering and crafting and leveling aspects, and the storyline and characters are cute, so I am glad I bought it. The little codex with the creatures and plants is an adorable concept.

Reading some of the negative comments, I don't necessarily agree with people's complaints about the "fetch requests not being motivating". For me, advancing the storyline, getting cutscenes and helping the villagers was motivating and felt meaningful, and the quality of life improvements you can buy were nice enough to want too. If you don't find that motivating enough, I guess it's not for you, sure. 
As for the game being difficult because "some animals are only found certain times of day" and "you have to really plan ahead", I can only say that Stardew Valley is much, much more complicated than this (to the point where reading the wiki is near essential) and that seems fine too. This game is not hard to succeed at, the mainline story quests do not have a time limit and you can freely decide which optional moneymaking quests to take on.

116592356.review:
I love this game. The art, the animation, the lush environments, and aesthetic themes are so charming. However, it breaks my heart to say I cannot recommend this game in its current state. 

The core gameplay mechanics of crafting and socializing with NPCs is one I love, but this game fails to properly engage the player with these mechanics in a meaningful way. In an attempt to impart major lore and overarching narrative, the tutorial stages of the game become cluttered with rambling dialogue and a linear quest progression that feels more restrictive than it ought to be. 

I think it was a mistake for the developers to start players off with such tedious and slow progression. Inventory space is comically small for the various crafting ingredients and multiple stages of item refinement required to craft a single item. Ingredients themselves all have a unique, but time-intensive gathering mechanic that does not have incremental improvement. The pacing of refining materials is locked behind progression. You start off only crafting items a single unit at a time and it takes too long and too many different resources to improve.

This pacing feels unnecessarily punishing and is a physical strain on the hands as there are several inputs required by the player in any given step and no way to automate these processes. Too many elements of the game have a stamina or breaking mechanic that creates conflict in managing your resources and inventory space. Quests are time sensitive. Certain resources and NPCs have limited availability throughout the day and night cycle. Time management takes a lot of trial and error. You'll find yourself frequently exiting to the main menu to pause and plan out your next steps.

This isn't even scratching the surface on the game's other more obvious technical problems. The keyboard controls are a joke. They hurt to play and cannot be remapped. The developers should take responsibility and warn players that the game is not optimized for keyboard and mouse. Even if you are using a gamepad, there is a lot of un-intuitive menuing and you are not paused while doing it. 

The unintentionally stressful gameplay really does not live up to its warmhearted, soothing story theme, and really need serious rebalancing and reworking before I can recommend anyone drop money on it.

116558493.review:
I just finished the early access of this game, and I really loved it! The art style and character designs are amazing, and the world is really cute and fun to explore. It was a surprisingly long early access version that really captivated me, but there were a few specific things I feel like could be improved for a more final version of the game (I'll try to keep this as spoiler-friendly as possible!).

First, the dialogue. As many others have noted, it's tedious to get through, and I have skipped passed important information numerous times and had to try to figure out controls or directions after the fact. It seems like the dialogue may have originally been in a different language and translated directly over to English because of the manner of speaking the characters have . If this is the case, I think it explains the clunkiness of the dialogue; both the literal translations of words plus the manner of speaking that is also directly translated over may lead to awkwardness in the dialogue that ends up causing us to skip through dialogue and missing important information.

Along with the potential direct translation, there are a couple of moments when dialogue could be excluded. For example, you will work on a puzzle in order to achieve a direct result (unlocking an area). Once you complete the puzzle, the game shows us that the area unlocked, but then Ellie and her hat have four or so lines of dialogue asking if something happened and then confirming that something must've happened. The dialogue here isn't necessary though, because we knew the objective coming into the puzzle and saw what happened as a result. It's something small, but following "show, don't tell" will help the dialogue issue even more.

Lastly, the only other thing that bothered me was the amount of stamina restoration items you receive when, so far, the game hasn't given a reason to use those items yet. I only gather ingredients when I need them and focus on the quests rather than constantly making rounds to gather things. Even when I did try that strategy, I quickly ran out of storage space and didn't end up using all of the ingredients I happened to save by the end. So, with my limited storage space and stockpile of commonly-used ingredients, I really didn't have room for the fruit and other recovery items since I never used them.

Another issue with the stamina is that I usually had plenty to do everything and more that I wanted to do in a day and found myself having to kill time before I could go to bed. Basically, just got bored.

In my opinion, sprinting around and/or certain actions should cost more stamina. It would make sense for players to struggle to be able to do EVERYTHING in a day, forcing players to prioritize quests and tasks over others and also making the player panic a little if they are out too late at night and it hits 11pm. 

All in all, the game is very unique with great characters, a great world, and interesting controls. I'm sure that, should there be a final version of the game, it will be amazing. I can't wait to play more!

116550994.review:
60 Sec Game Review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GhuRgf3UGfs

Short Version:
The game is a solid 7.0 even in early access standards

Complete Version:
Little Witch in the Woods is a RPG Adventure Game
It tells the story of Ellie, an apprentice witch, after she gets stuck in a forest and have to find a way to survive among its wilderness.

In the making of this Review, the game is still in Early access.

You will craft potions, collect materials and discover the world around you.
If you like games similar to Stardew Valley, you will probably like this one

This game is single player only, though

The pixel art is gorgeous
The majority of characters is likable
The music is good

The gameplay is fine, but a little bit repetitive
You will explore, get quests, collect things, process it, make potions, deliver it, upgrade things and repeat all over again

Note: you can’t change your controls.
Some people recommend to play it in a controller, but I used a keyboard and had no issues with it.

Some people complained about performance issues (myself included), others did not have any of it.

Note: you can only have one saving slot, so, if it gets corrupted, you are doomed.

The game is a solid 7.0 even in early access standards

there are practically no side-quests whatsoever. the only thing that you can do is collect secrets called "ritoring's gifts" which dont do anything at all currently.

the main story point is that ellie wants to restore the village by bringing back the people to the village after a plant destroyed the village and almost all the villagers left. problem is that the village seems... dead, soulless, as if nothing that you are doing, except the main quest, makes any difference whatsoever. this game is as linear as it gets.

the game IS still in early access and the release time is somewhere in 2023 so there is still hope that those problems will be fixed but i highly doubt it since those are core gameplay problems and not some small quality of life problems

i am still going to give it a positive review cuz its cute as heck

116549482.review:
I'll preface by stating that I bought this game with my own money.

Overall rating in its current state with the content currently available: 8/10

This game is NOT like Stardew Valley. It's a darn shame article writers continue to mention Stardew at all online. This is a gather/craft/quest focused RPG. You upgrade your facilities, your stash, your inventory and your ability as a potion-making witch. You gather ingredients for your potions and unlock new areas to explore to help you do what needs to be done. 

The controls are clunky, but they are easy to get used to with a little patience and practice. -- My hope is that controls will be customizable as time goes on, but now that I've put so many hours into this key profile, it's really quite intuitive.

The Korean to English translation isn't consistent. -- Minor grievance to me, but some might find it off-putting.

There is a lack of variety in daily quests. -- As the player progresses through the game and unlocks more areas with more ingredients, the daily quests don't change and stay on par with the main quests' demands. I spent too much time in the beginner area farming older materials for daily quests imo. This left me feeling rushed trying to get daily materials while still trying to get what was needed for the main quests and side quests.

Potion book is unwieldy when you are wanting to make a lot of the same kind of potions in one sitting. -- Please have the potion book remember the last ingredients, heat and stir you used. Also add the ability to favorite recipes that you use a ton. Keep it limited to 3 recipes or something. Maybe also keep it an upgradeable thing that you unlock with currency, or perhaps introduce player levels dealing with recollecting recipes so you don't have to constantly check your book. Given that there are daily quests, it gets old very quickly to go back and forth in the book and the inventory. *I'd like to add a disclaimer that I have not upgraded the cauldron, nor have I explored super in-depth into the upgrade systems in place. Perhaps some of these things already exist and I just don't know about it yet.

Travel and mobility is great. -- You don't feel burdened by travel mechanics in this game. Default move speeds are generous. The broom is quick, but be careful maneuvering too quickly in tight spaces.

Storytelling is fun and engaging if you give it a chance and skip the fluff. -- No complaints about the amount of dialogue. It's skippable, so why would I complain? I skim read to get the gist of what's going on and spam skip the fluff that many people would probably find endearing. So far, I've enjoyed what's going on in the story set up. I'm sure I'll read everything when the game releases!

The gathering mechanics are what shine to me. There's small amounts of uniqueness to how you gather certain items and that keeps things fresh. There's variety and inspiration behind the ingredients for sure! Some ingredients require a bit of brainpower and trial and error to obtain. This is really awesome for those who love to puzzle out how things work.

I am very glad I decided to support this game. It may be early release, but I've already put more than enough hours in it to make up the cost. I hope people that love this game share it with others and spread the word so that the devs get the backing they need to really make something special.

116533796.review:
I'll get this out of the way first: I recommend that you wait to buy it (if you want a decent amount of content). I've finished the main campaign within 10 hours of play. This game is VERY early access. Even so, I absolutely love it.

I really enjoy it so far. The art and music are great! I like the potion making mechanics; I think they're fun. The characters are enjoyable and some of the world-building is interesting. I especially like the witch's encyclopedia and that you need to draw the flora or fauna before it is officially added into it. It's also helpful for when you forget how to make a potion/candy.

The only part I didn't like was that it can be kind of grindy to run around and grab all of the commonly used ingredients. Making maple essence was the only ingredient I really dreaded needing because it's used often (or at least in the recipes I made a lot), and it's kind of annoying to get because it's slower and out of the way. You can't quickly grab it on the way to somewhere else like you do with squishy chubs or witch root. Being able to rebind controls would be a plus, but I got used to them pretty quickly.

So, if you don't care about the amount of content available right now, I can wholeheartedly recommend playing!

116434852.review:
Personally, I think it's too early to give this game a negative review but I also can't justify paying $16 for the small amount of joy you may get from it.

The game, by itself, is good. The art style is cute, the music is nice, the atmosphere is relaxing! The game is similar to Stardew Valley, as many have mentioned but like the kiddie pool version of it. There's no where near as much world and nowhere near as much to do, which can be expected from an early access game.

However for the most part, all you're going to be doing in this game is tickling a few creatures and whacking a few plants to get materials to make potions that either advance the story or get you coins. Day in, day out. You unlock a new area, in the story, you get a new ingredient, you make a new kind of potion that either advances the story line or can be made for daily quests for coin. Wash. Rinse. Repeat.

The only break from that, is that you have a few areas and 'secrets' that require certain potions to make to explore. Which returns you to that grind to get the parts to make it. It was fun for maybe the first hour or three but soon it becomes a daily chore that has no purpose. The easiest way to put it for you Stardew Players is, it's the game if you buy a Member Ship card and have to farm corn over and over to pay for the village upgrades. The monotony hits quick and the game instantly loses any appeal it had.

Another thing many players complain about is the dialogue, I personally had no problem with it as for awhile I was invested in the story but there is no skip option and there is a LOT of dialogue that you cannot avoid. I would recommend if the developers either A, added a skip option for the players who aren't interested or B, added a some of the dialogue in little gab windows that pop up near the top of the window so they can still move and play while the main character is yapping to her hat as 9/10 times, they're saying something that doesn't really NEED to be up in the players face.

TLDR; The game has potential, it's cute and fun but at the present it's lackluster and monotonous after a while with slow grindy progression and a very small amount of gameplay. 

The game will probably improve drastically when it's finished and has more interesting content to take part in, but for $16 it's little more than a flash game where you interact with creatures and plants to make keys that advance the plot or give you money.

What a cute little game! I cannot wait to see the final, full game.

And that i mean literally:

It is cute. The graphics are adorable, the animals and plants you interact with are well animated (squishing bunny-like squishychubs!? screaming mandrake? omigosh!)

It is little. Well, right now. It is early access, and in this case it apparently means we see only some part of the game.
I'd call it the opening chapters. At the 'end' - marked by a simple 'Thank you for playing' - you still have several dangling plot lines, or at least indicators for further development. I won't go into detail here, you will notice.
So promising!

And yes, i liked it, and I am really curious how it will continue.
The overall look and approach is welcoming and makes you want more. The exploration and gathering is well made, and the crafting approach much better than other games. Big plus for that!


What i did not fully like:
The opening is quite long. It is more a click-along story or movie that introduces you to the main characters and their background, and sets the plot. It is well made, and has many funny comments. But it is lengthy, and might be a barrier for people who do not like to read lots of talk bubbles in a game, just to start.


My personal wish list:
- reconfigurable controls, like switching the yes/no or do/cancel activity at least
- re-check the assignment of items to storage places. imo all potions/candys/.. should go to the potions storage
- also storage management: please allow larger stacks in inventory and storage
Maybe also the possiblity to acquire different outfits? And change your own appearance.

Looking forward to the final game!

116406628.review:
I didn't want to downvote this game because it is absolutely adorable, and if there were a neutral option, I would have gone with that. With how it is now, I will recommend for people to buy it on sale or hold off until the game is fixed up some more. 

As you will probably notice, most of the reviews only have a few hours in them, even the positive ones. That's because the game is too tedious to play in its current state. The controls, for one, are bound in a counterintuitive way. Movement is via arrow keys instead of WASD. You can't use the mouse to click on menu stuff (even the main menu), but that's bearable compared to having to navigate using the arrow keys when you play a hundred other games that follow WASD. 

For people who are not too much into random banter between characters, you will have to suffer through an inordinate amount of small talk (or "chit-chat" as the game puts it) before getting to the point. I understand that the devs put in a ton of work into the conversations and it should be appreciated, but also please understand that there are people like me who only get to play in short bursts and cannot spend time swimming through 34 lines of conversation just to be allowed to get to the one line that tells us to make this or that potion to move the story along. (I won't complain about typos or grammatical errors as others have since I didn't really pay attention enough for it to bother me.)

Speaking of moving the story along, the game takes its sweet time slow walking you through how things work, but is also incredibly lacking. You normally want to hit the ground running and just start crafting a bunch of potions and build your witchy business up, but nope, you have to go through the tutorial, one quest at a time. Every single feature is locked behind a quest. But somehow the quests will not just tell you straight up what you need to do, you have to go about it in a roundabout way, talk to everyone in town, before you are finally taught how to do the most basic thing.

BUT, if you manage to put up with all that, and eventually get to the part that (mostly) allows you to do whatever you want, it is ok. The game, like I said, is adorable and if I could play this on my Switch lying down, instead of in front of my PC in between work stuff, I would have more patience for it. As it is, if you are like me, I do not recommend it in its current state.

This is a lovely game with a lot of heart and a lot of humour! I quickly came to love our little delinquent witch, and I'm excited to see where her story takes us.  Movement and actions feel very fluid, and even in this early version I never felt that the game was giving me busywork that didn't advance the plot.  The fact that resources spawn reliably was a nice bonus that I didn't realise I'd appreciate so much - if I need something, I know where to go rather than wandering the map and crossing my fingers. The potion mechanics are fun and worked into the story well.

The only (very minor) hiccups I encountered were that the day seems to move quickly (or perhaps I'm just trying to do too much?) which is pretty brutal when Ellie will crash out at midnight. It also affects fairly major resources such as the Witches' Catalogue. No midnight-potion brewing for you, Ellie - get to bed!

It reminds me of a cute little mix of Animal Crossing and Stardew Valley, but it's still its own amazing game so far! I will admit, the personality of Ellie kind of frustrates me. Her entire personality is just that she gets bored with every single little thing. That's it, that's her personality. I couldn't relate at all each time she couldn't even read because she was TOO bored. But the game play and the other characters and the crafting made it pretty easy to overlook.

Can't wait for more! Thank you!

116388980.review:
I really enjoy this game! It's like Stardew + A Short Hike + Calico, in my opinion. 

Pros for me:
- Fun story and character design
- Pretty animations and sounds (love the "success" animation when brewing potions!)
- No punishment if you stay out too late and are transported to your bed!
- The challenges of collecting materials feel pretty well-balanced to me
- The mechanics are fun, easy to play, easy to feel proficient

Cons for me:
- The controls! I might have missed a way to change this, but it uses Z and the arrow keys primarily, which was frustrating because I don't use a standard keyboard (no built-in arrow keys)
- It's hard to verbalize, but the game needs a LOT of clicking/tapping to get through dialogue. Every dialogue seems like it has 5-10 "lines" to get through, just to buy something or deliver an item, and I found it annoying.

And the ultimate con: Not enough content! Really looking forward to more :) 

Oh, and I actually don't think I ran into any major bugs!

116388224.review: This game reminds me of stardew valley. The time in the game goes by fairly quickly and you spend the whole day foraging to make potions that you may need for quests. If you like games like that, this is right up your alley, The artwork and storytelling is so cute and aesthetic too. I will say that if you don't enjoy tedious gameplay then  this maybe isn't the game for you, as it is quite time consuming--there just isn't enough time in one day to do everything that i want! lol

116386664.review: The game gives the right amount of time to get used to controls and offers a guide at the bottom when you make potions. Since the entire game becomes updated/when all the quests will be out, in 2023, the game (so far) took me about 7-8 hours to catch up to where the quests end so far. I think the price is reasonable considering how in depth the world and characters are. I can't wait for the game to be finished and meet all the new characters and experience the quests! I look forward to it! Definitely recommend to anyone who is interested!

116348767.review:
I really enjoyed this! The style is adorable and I really love the story so far. There are a few translation issues but they are few and far between. I see that a few people say that the gameplay is repetitive but I personally love that! The potion making and material gathering is repetitive but very enjoyable and calming. The potion materials have different ways to be gathered and it adds the tiniest bit of nuance between each item. It is a very dialogue heavy game but the story is interesting so I enjoy all the dialogue and find myself constantly talking to characters to try and find new character interactions, side quests, and general information about the world and characters.

Pros:
- Cute game
- Fun story with a great cast of characters (and more to look forward to in the full game).
- Enjoyable gameplay

Cons:
- The keyboard controls do take a little getting used to but if you're like me and start playing this game religiously the controls become super easy and second nature.
- The few translation issues take you out of the story for a second.

Personal Question:
- Upstairs in the With's House the bookshelf we investigate also has a window like it has the function of a chest but I haven't been able to find what could go in it. Is that supposed to happen? If it is another chest what does go in it?

Things I would like to see in the full game:
- Some kind of broom upgrade so that is needs to be fixed less often/doesn't break so fast.
- A way for us to know how much potions cost if we've sold them before. That would be really handy.

All in all, a super fun and cute game that I highly recommend! There is an enjoyable amount of content within the early access but you could also wait for the full game to come out! If you like Stardew Valley and Animal Crossing you will probably love this game.

116347824.review:
very gorgeous game. stunning visuals and the soundtracks and sound effects are perfect! however.
I wouldn't recommend this game right _now_ as I want to have faith that it'll improve in the final version. I've played about 3 hours into it and so far it's just been:
⋄ long dialogues
⋄ endless fetch quests, like all you do is run around collecting, delivering.
⋄ feels like the characters lack personality/are very bland
⋄ some of the dialogue options feel super disorganised. Some options have text cut off because it doesn't fit the buttons.

a few things I think would be a nice asset are (some are just nitpicks, js.)
⋄ change some font faces to match the art style (i.e pixel font to go with the pixel art.)
⋄ pause screen could definitely look better.
⋄ key binding options / mouse control + keyboard. like a point and click.
⋄ when you are brewing potions in the cauldron you should be able to simultaneously check your book and brew without having to quit the activity.
⋄ save points / save on the go.

I've been waiting for a while for this game to come out, and am impressed with everything you can do as an early access title.   
 I love that it's not just another Stardew/ Harvest Moon clone, even though I would still definitely enjoy it if it was!  It's a nice mix of resource gathering and crafting balanced with more a fun story and lots of unique characters that you get to interact with and know better.  I just finished the main game content, and can't wait for more!  It's a nice and relaxing game that gives you a lot of world and characters to explore as much as you want.  I think they've done a great job with this title so far.

 Honestly the negative reviews I've seen note that the game has a long way to go, which should just be a given with early access titles.  The developers have been quick with updates and patches, and take user feedback and either make actions on it right away, or explain why there may be a delay before seeing user requested features.

- Rewarding to unlock new areas and help the town
- Cute animals (Bubble lizards are my favourite)

- Puzzles arent too hard to solve (as someone who hates puzzles this is good for me lol)

Cons:
- Feel like overtime collecting the same ingredients will be reptitive

What I would love to be added:
- Small garden option e.g Pokemon where you plant one and get 4 back

Overall, give this game a go! It's adorable, light hearted and great for casual players!

Absolutely fantastic game, especially for early access. 

I've played all of the available content for the early access and I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys games like Stardew Valley, or any games with simple yet long lists of crafting recipes (that can be used to traverse environmental obstacles or quests.)

Aesthetic:
- Very cute art style that flows together without huge texture clipping issues.
- Simple yet engaging story.
- Fourth wall breaks for comedic effect.
- Variety of character personalities.

Practical:
- Confusing controls (at first. But feel good to use when used to them.)
- No way to adjust control bindings.
- Ability to skip time, which isn't used often, but oh boy when it's needed it is super useful.
- Cut-scenes leave you at the beginning of the area they take place in and most often only start when entering said area. (Helps with disorientation)
- Very few bugs encountered in early access.

Only problem I kept facing was wanting more time in the day, but nothing is super rushed for time in this game. I just like to clear out the whole map of crafting materials as they reset every day.

I look forward to the full release and any expansions they might release! Keep up the good work! <3 :]

(Edit: Another thing I really enjoyed was the lack of locking days when completing events. If you have the time in the day and the resources you can progress with multiple story events in one in game day. Please don't change that because it really makes the game feel nicer when I have more control over my progression speed. <3)

116204123.review:
Little Witch of the Woods is a soothing and calming experience of exploring the skills of a witch and working from Apprentice to Master Witch. You play as Ellie, a young witch who is bored of school and learning and wants to get out to strengthen and develop her skills and understanding.

The main aim of the game is to create Potions and Candies, done so by using items and materials that can be gathered from the main area, and utilising them to continue exploring other areas to fill up your Encyclopaedia and support the World and NPCs. Little Witch has a gathering system like that of Stardew Valley, but includes the Potion/Candy Creation System, which uses various tools to prepare the materials, and the Cauldron to create the Potion or Candy.

The game starts with a lengthy introduction to Ellie and the story of Little Witch in the Woods, all set on a train, whilst you get use to the controls and how to interact with characters or items within the world, and you're introduced the dialog system of having chatting options, questioning options, and side-quest options. The introduction helps set up the feeling and experience of the game and provides a strong start for the player.

The game itself is very engaging, and you’re always going to feel like you’re doing something. This is through providing motivation in terms of upgrading work tools, to creating Potions/Candies for daily hand ins. Little Witch makes you feel like there is something to do, even if you do not think there is. Some gatherable items can only be gathered at certain times of the day, to interacting with NPCs within the area and getting to know their interests.

Although still in Early Access, there can be a few bugs in terms of interaction with items or gathering, however most of the game plays very well and has been a very enjoyable experience. The main story ends off after following the main quest line and some main objectives have been completed, so there is a sudden halt to the story, but you’re still able to continue playing free roam. Below is a Pros/Cons list of the game from my point of view:

Pros:
- Great Potion/Candy Creation System – although simplistic -, but includes different ways to create Potions/Candies through Cauldron Heat and Stirring options
- Great puzzle system, which is simplistic enough in terms of how to utilise potions or candies
- A so-far cute and easy-to-get-into story, but offers enough mystery to encourage you to continue and explore further
- Great art style from the locations and areas to the sprites of the characters, and includes a Date and Day/Night cycle 
- NPCs help make the game feel alive, and offer a variety of personalities, through normal interaction to shop usage
- Clear instructions towards what to do and how to progress, and offers a menu to show progress of quests
- Quests and Side-Quests always encourage you to do something, whether it be for gathering or creating potions/candies, however, you do not feel the need to rush anything
- An easy to access Encyclopaedia system, encouraging you to write down gatherable materials and wildlife around the area, whilst holding Potion/Candy recipes
- A simplistic inventory and storage system to hold gatherable materials and crafted materials

Cons: 
- English translation can be confusing at times when it comes to reading dialogue, with some mistakes in terms of words or spellings
- The Prologue is very lengthy and can be slow
- Although nap system is a good implementation, it is limited to where you can nap and for how long
- Inventory and storage system could have a “Sort” button or include options to sort inventory/storage
- There is a lack of an Autosave system for the moment, so before quitting, make sure to save
- A set controls scheme in place for Keyboard and Mouse, which can lead to hands aching due to placement of keys/controls, or dis encourage players that are not used to RPGMaker controls

Overall, I have had a positive and enjoyable experience with Little Witch of the Woods, and have completed the main story/side quests that are accessible within 8 hours of game play. I look forward to Little Witch's updates and am eager to see what they will implement and how they will improve the game.

116119852.review:
Warning: slight spoilers

I don't normally write reviews for games and have never played a game in early access before but, the Little Witch in the Woods charmed me with its gameplay, story and characters. 

Pros:
- Gorgeous art style - animations of potion effects and characters are beautiful 
- Interesting characters and the introduction of said characters 
- Potion mechanics and gathering is enjoyable 
- Some have said the dialogue is too long which I agreed with at first. However, once you really get into the game, you appreciate the witty and well written conversations between the characters -- some speech is redundant but most just adds to your immersion 
- The game is very good at steering players in the right direction without revealing too much and ruining the story
- Roy. Who doesn't love the juxtaposition of a stoic man being a flower lover? 
- The soundtrack is super relaxing and cute 

Cons:
- I would recommend playing with a controller as the key binds for keyboard can be a little confusing if you are not familiar with these type of games -- however, the game is by no means unplayable with the default key binds, it would just require a little time to familiarise yourself with them 


Hopes for the full release:
- Friendship levels with villagers and potentially a love interest? (which is likely as one potion speaks of creating a romantic atmosphere) -- I would like to give gifts to the villagers and learn more about their interests 
- A way to improve the stamina function -- I like how your max stamina depletes as the day goes on, however, once you get further into the game and have more materials to gather it can be a little irritating to see how quickly it dries up. Of course you can just eat food but, if you have spent the day gathering, you can't fill up the whole bar to full again so, maybe they could introduce a temporary increase in stamina potion or an increase in endurance when foraging and bug catching? 
- There are upgrades in terms of machinery (extractor, cauldron and roaster) -- I would like to see an upgrade in gathering, maybe a luck boosting potion that increases the likelihood of drop rates from animals or double the amount of plants/fruit picked 
- Maybe a broom upgrade - using sturdier materials to increase the durability (not necessarily the speed as I think it has a good gauge on that part already) 
- When you craft a potion it can either be correct or incorrect -- I would like to see the animation on the successful potion be a little more colourful? It is currently a grey-ish colour and doesn't really scream successful potion -- WITCH IT UP! -- make the cauldron explode and be over the top!!! Potentially unique potion animations per potion (I do realise this would be very hard to develop but, it would be amazing to see that level of detail) 
- Introduce the self-save option a little earlier in the game -- it can just cause stress as players feel like they can't leave the game when they want for fear their progress will be erased 
- I would love the game to potentially explore Highlion either at the very end of the game or as a follow up game -- to see where Ellie was going to stay and what her life would have been like if not for staying in Wisteria -- Furthermore, playing as Ellie's mother and seeing her relationship with Virgil would be very interesting as a sort of prelude game to this one. 
- There is a lot of unexplored history of Ellie's time in magic school and Ellie's mother so, a flashback would be really cool to see -- or flashbacks to certain events in magic school that got Ellie into trouble (the story behind her finishing 2nd in her year but also being rebellious is a fun trait so, seeing more of that side to her would be very cool)
- Definitely interested in more villagers! as well as more lore building around the town and universe in general 
- Maybe one of the characters should warn Ellie that staying up past 12 is dangerous and she should sleep before then (since you faint in game after 12 am) 
- Maybe add a baking function -- it could be funny that a witch would need to use a basic oven to make food and not via their cauldron 
- Waiting for Rubrum to brew and pour me some tea as well as buy Roy's flowers. 
- Potentially a change in outfit (obviously not the hat (Virgil) as they are our companion) -- maybe a different look for our broom or a new cloak (purely aesthetic) 

All in all, for a game in early-access, I think the Little Witch in the Woods is very well made, you can tell a lot of love went into this game as it gives you an overall feeling of happiness and relaxation. I am very excited to see how the game will develop with future updates.

116119601.review:
Really adorable & relaxing! Characters have colorful personalities, Design of the environment is nice, love the buildings and areas. I love the main character & her companion! Also, the creatures here are so cute! I like that with each creature - animal/plants - there's a different way to interact with them, I think this is the first time I encounter this meta.

Control was a bit unusual but not an issue for me. 
Some improvements that I wish will happen in the full game:
- Visible money inventory bar, perhaps always staying on screen or when we open notes. Currently we can only view our money when opening a shop menu, making it difficult to track how much we need to purchase something.
- During potion crafting, can add the potion recipe button to open the book, so it's easier to know what material & steps needed. My memory is not good remembering every materials& steps needed for each potion :'3
- I think the night cycle is too dark and can be lighter, but maybe it's just me. It makes the glow effects more pop up but a bit hard to see other stuff that's not glowing.
- Maybe a teleport tool and a map we can open anywhere?
- Have issues with the pumpkin terrier monster that kept running, difficult to catch. In one case it's not dropping material because it's too close to the edge and disappears.
- Climbing with the vines there are some positions we can get stuck to. A bit difficult to manuever.
- Since it's a linear story driven game and not a sim maybe need something for endgame content, so if the story finishes there might be some things to do.

I guess that is all and if the dev read this I hope you'll consider my suggestions.
Can't wait for the game's full release!

116115083.review: This game is super cute! I have been watching for its release for a while now and finally got to play it today. It took me around 8 hours to beat the story-so-far and I am really impressed. I expected a stardew-inspired game, but they really focus more on a linear story built around crafting and exploration. I really liked the balance of being able to do what you want, but having key story points built around you as you craft and explore. Crafting itself also isn't very boring because there are layers to making a spell. First being gathering the ingredients, then creating essences/breaking down the ingredients, then combining them and setting the fire level and stir direction to create your potion or candy. It sounds a bit wordy in text, but it works and really lends itself nicely to the feeling of actually making a potion. The characters are super cute and well designed and all have their own personalities. I love the dialogue between the hat and your character as well. There is some good humor in the writing that keeps the story engaging. I am excited to see how the map expands, what new characters we will meet, what new gameplay mechanics we can see added, and how the story progresses. They've built a really nice foundation to start off with, now we just need to see where it goes.

116105970.review:
Okay so, I'm very picky about games I play and hate story driven games because often I can't play them a second time unless I really loved the game. I REALLY love this game. its cute its fun the crafting is easy to understand imo and its simplistic nature is perfect for a silly game. It'd be weird if a fun game had super complicated recipes.

 I only have a few things I'd like to see in game and I'll rank them based on how much I'd like that to happen (on a scale of 1-10), my reasoning and whether or not I think it will happen (0 being never and 5 being its a need)

1. Upgrading your witch hut. I really love acquiring and upgrading things in video games, in fallout and skyrim I spent an unhealthy amount of time building settlements and finding any collectables for display at my house. Or like in stardew valley where most house upgrades are for looks and merely to decorate. Great Seratonin boost to see how much I accomplished. Maybe Kayla/Kyla could sell furniture and Roy could sell vases and hanging plants like the in game ingredients or food. A kitchen too to make your own food for energy. 10/10 would LOVE    3/5 could get in the way of the story plus the little patch of land is small but outside looks dont always matter and being able to cook for energy would be so fun. 

2. Character customization (you probs saw this coming) again a useless in game seritonin boost but its so fun customizing your own character and feeling like you are actually playing but this game seems to clearly follow Ellie. I was wondering if it mattered to the story if she had black hair or could change into regular clothes instead of dragging that robe through the dirty forest. She was on a trip so naturally she'd have extra clothes? The reason I ranked it so low on likelihood is because of how much work it'll be to add customizations to the sprite that pops up very often and not just on your character, I mean in the text boxes. thats already so many animations as of right now in early access. 8/10 would like to see it

3. Friendship bars. I'm gonna rank this 0.1/5 immediately because it seems the friendship is very story driven. I would say maybe they could give you items every so often but they seem to be set up to already begin to do that, like Enite already gives you pie, Rumbrum is always brewing tea so maybe down the line you get some, you get candy from that stranger in the woods it just seems like a story driven system. 5/10 I'd be happen to have it but I wouldn't mind either way.

BUGS
I haven't experienced anything major just a few small annoyances

1. the terrier guys that you have to chase: while filling the bar is they happen to get out of range right as you finish it starts you over and that usually happens after I've been chasing for a while. Once I chased him for a solid 2 minutes and he dropped nothing but he did the little disappearing thing when you succeed. that bothered me a bit but not game breaking 10/10 bothers me alot when  it happens but I over collect so it's never for an emergency when I'm trying to get it. 4/5

2. the twigs falling interrupts your progress. very minor annoyance and the game already lets you collect faster after being partially harvested. 3/5  5/10 I stand off to the side to avoid it happening so I would be happy if it was fixed but I dont mind

3. In the quest to find the prickly vine core, it gives you blue chalk but my inventory was full so I had no clue where it went for quite a while, I just happened to look in my lunar chest on accident to see it in there. There might already be a little pop up that says (item moved to lunar chest) but I missed that if it did and I was sad I couldnt figure out what was wrong. 5/5 must have. 10/10 would love to see

4. The roaster, I had completely forgotten I was suppose to get the handle from the merchant so I spent a lot of time doing my quest to "get to the point where I get the handle" and when every recipe Ineeded next required the roaster I had to look it up. I do have memory issues so this may not have been a problem to many other people but maybe add it as a small side quest or a little notebook thing we could have to log what we did each day like in the old days of pokemon (or new its beein a while since i played). 5/5 must have 10/10 really would like to see.

I did not expect to write this much about it but I just love this game so much and can't wait to see how awesome it becomes.

116065880.review:
Found this on Game Pass and ended up loving it enough to buy it.
Just to list some good things about the game:
- The characters, art, and animations are pretty great. Your character Ellie is especially interesting, and a lot of creatures are just downright adorable.
- The soundtrack is pretty good.
- I found the world, its characters, and story to be interesting enough to keep me invested.
- Gathering and crafting is fun
- Quests and recipes are neatly presented to you.
- Have I mentioned that Ellie is adorable?
 
And the not-so-good:
- Character dialogues definitely need a second pass. Some conversations feel too dragged out, and some don't flow well at all. Whoever's translating these needs to do better.
- Gathering is fun for the first several hours, but it becomes repetitive/tedious as your crafting and gathering requirements grow larger. It would be nice if we can upgrade our gathering tools to gather more/faster.
- Can't rebind controls on either KB&M/Gamepad.
- Can't use your mouse to interact with the UI.
- QoL issues like purchasing and leaving conversations taking one too many buttons to execute. I shouldn't have tap B on my gamepad several times to leave a conversation.

Overall, this has been very fun. I'd recommend this to anyone looking for a casual gathering/exploration/crafting game with a cute and fun story.

116065328.review:
Ok so: I had this game on my wishlist for about a year and was so excited to play this when the early release dropped. Like most of the other reviews I have a few pros and cons. 
Pros:
-Adorable art
-Love the general idea
-Adore gathering all potion ingredients. 

Cons:
-The dialogue is a bit long winded. I found myself just smashing the Z button to get through some of the longer parts. 
-Controls are a little odd, I've never played a game with these specific controls so I often found myself miss-clicking trying to open my menu or select something. 
-It's a little frustrating getting some of the ingredients as it's not super intuitive (at least for me, the feathers are kind of a pain)
-SUPER small storage when the game starts. 
-When it hits midnight it just kind of resets to the next day? 

Overall, this game is so cute, and I really loved playing it. I only have about 50 hours on the clock (versus my 400+ in stardew) but as soon as an update drops, I am running back to it. Super excited to keep playing and for sure recommend this to anyone looking for a relaxing, cute game to unwind to.

116061438.review:
Little Witch in the Woods is a cute, low-key, chill game about apprentice witch Ellie and her hat. You solve puzzles and explore the landscape while selling potions on the side for cash. I think the pixel art is just gorgeous - probably the game's standout quality. 

The writing (in English) definitely needs an editor who knows the language better. I hope that improves in the future. I have read worse translations, though, and I would like to point out that the best translation cannot save bad writing - but here, the charming story shines through even a rough translation. There were several parts that made me laugh and smile! I especially appreciate that the main character Ellie has a chaotic, mischievous personality, and drives the plot with her decisions. 

I understand that some people will be put off by the current state of the writing. If you can't stand awkward phrasing or grammatical mistakes, wait until it's out of early access. But if you're willing to approach the game with a charitable spirit and the right mindset, you will find it a soothing experience!

116061333.review: Saw the game online before release and was really looking forward to it. It's exactly what I envisioned, a cute, cozy Witch-RPG. Even though it's a pixel art game just like Stardew Valley, it has nothing in common with it. The world we play Ellie in is beautifully designed and the beings we meet are just cute^^. The game has a lot of potential and I'm looking forward to how it continues.
